Soon enough, it's June (じゅん) which is the middle of the year so everything is soon. Jokes on them though. Halloween will be in season forever now. Soon it will be Halloween. Soon it will be time for candy. Soon June will end and people will forget about everything else.

mnemonics.meaning: When your ear is crossed with sound, it catches it like a net, and sends it to your heart for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper listen. Imagine the whole process of sound going through your ear and to your heart, then the gears turning to really understand what someone is saying. It's a real listen, not a fake non-heart listen.
mnemonics.reading: You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth. Focus on listening, and focus on their message about Mrs. Chou. Feel afraid about the future because of it.

mnemonics.meaning: You give your servant a gun along with some other products to look to. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products. Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
mnemonics.reading: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well. Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.

mnemonics.meaning: The omen radical and the omen kanji are the same! If you know the omen radical, you know the omen kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world. You can clarify with the person telling you the omen several things: "Do you believe in the omen about Mrs. Chou destroying the world?" "When will this omen about Mrs. Chou come true?" etc. As long as you're associating omen with Mrs. Chou you should be good, so keep harping on that. Anyway, whenever you hear any kind of omen (omen is a radical in the kanji), there's a good chance it's going to be about Mrs. Chou.

mnemonics.meaning: The weight of life on your sword is big when you pledge to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword. Imagine holding up your sword and pledging to protect the lives of everyone in this city. It's a big deal!
mnemonics.reading: Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food. Would you pledge to give up cake to show everyone how serious you are about protecting life?

mnemonics.meaning: Destroy a lantern with your knife and you'll be punished. Even if it was your own lantern, why stab it with a knife? You could have recycled that. I will punish you for lantern stabbing and pollution!
mnemonics.reading: I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment. The next time you want to stab a lantern with a knife, think about how good cake tastes and stop. Remember, DARE (Don't Attack Reusable Electronics)!

mnemonics.meaning: A greenhouse is the newest power of the city you decided to recruit. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless. Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
mnemonics.reading: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse. Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader presents you with a prize as reparation for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize. Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
mnemonics.reading: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for). Imagine receiving your reparations from the Shougun himself. You're angry at him for threatening you, wounding people, and cutting off the heads of people who go against him, but you take it anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone from your clan puts their fingers in the ground as a way to resist their lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. This is a protest! Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on! Imagine your entire clan putting their fingers in the ground in unison as a form of resistance. It's a moving sight.
mnemonics.reading: You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!" You make your choice to resist. He orders his guards to pull your fingers out of the ground, chop them into the size of tater tots, and then deep fry them. After they're done, the lord pops one in his mouth and says, "Oooh, resistance is delicious."

mnemonics.meaning: This door is big and you need to return it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them. Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
mnemonics.reading: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode. You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun calls out to the earth by shining down on it. The sun doesn't have a voice, unfortunately, so it calls out the only way it can, with its shining rays.
mnemonics.reading: This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan. Picture the Shougun standing in the shining sunlight. He's so bright and beautiful!

mnemonics.meaning: The skewer radical and the skewer kanji are exactly the same! Know your radicals, yo.
mnemonics.reading: Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it. Imagine trying to use this cushy skewer. It's the right shape (long, thin, pointy at one end), but every time you try to put something on it it squishes in on itself like a long marshmallow.

mnemonics.meaning: At this gate you're trying to get some beans through, but the measurements were off and you're starting to struggle. No matter how you push or pull these beans, they're just too big to get through the gate. "I'm really struggling here, I thought you said you measured these beans?" you ask the bean seller. "I did! I mean, I struggled with the measurements, I'm not very good at math..." Ugh.
mnemonics.reading: You continue to struggle because you need to get these beans to the other side of the gate and into とうきょう. You usually struggle a little when people want to bring things through the gate to とうきょう, but this is ridiculous. "How am I supposed to sell my beans if you struggle this much just to get them into とうきょう!" the bean seller shouts. It's making you struggle more, and beans start falling on your head, ripping their way out of their sack.

mnemonics.meaning: Happiness is a circle that's tenacious. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can. Be tenacious about happiness in your life. No matter how many times it slips away, don't give up. Keep going after it, because it will absolutely come back if you're tenacious enough.
mnemonics.reading: Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it. Will someone take the shoe sometimes? Yeah, but the shih tzu doesn't give up. That's how you need to be with happiness. Kids, be tenacious!

mnemonics.meaning: Your foot is a little red and you can see traces of ink streaked on it. Where did these traces come from? You look closer at your foot, examining the traces of red ink, and slowly the night before comes back to you.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out the traces of red ink were from a sexy (せき) rave you were at last night. Everyone around you looked so sexy, with their glow-in-the-dark paint, so you decided to put some of the red ink on your feet so everyone could see your sexy dancing. As you feel the sexy, confident feelings return, you see traces of the ink on your carpet, all the way from the door to the bed. Dang it.

mnemonics.meaning: A triceratops with a moon knife can whittle down anything. Imagine the triceratops with its little moon knife, doing some whittling. Hand it anything and it will whittle it down.
mnemonics.reading: Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく). Check out the sack that holds all the things that the triceratops whittled down. Go ahead and look through it, it's quite filled.

mnemonics.meaning: Your aim is your aim. What are you aiming for? Despite looking like an adjective, this is a noun, so be careful!
mnemonics.reading: My aim is near (ねら) to here. Right there, in fact.

sentences: この教科書の狙いは上述の通りです。
The aim of this textbook is as mentioned above.
どんな問題にも目的と狙いがあります。
Any problem has objectives and aims.
どうせアフィ狙いかステマの釣り記事だろ。
It must be a clickbait article aimed at affiliate programs or stealth marketing.

mnemonics.meaning: Confront your body? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's antibody?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてボスに逆らって、そのウィルスへの抗体を作り出そうとするのですか？予防接種を受ける！
Why do you defy your boss and try to build up antibodies to the virus? Get a vaccination!

mnemonics.meaning: An afflicted someone is someone who is a patient / medical patient. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji and you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there's rendaku on the second kanji so it turns to じゃ.

sentences: その患者は、左足が麻痺してもなお、サッカー選手になれるという希望に固執していた。
That patient clung to his dream of being a soccer player even though his left leg was paralyzed.

mnemonics.meaning: I respond to your recruitment with this application to try and join your group.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 応募用紙は裁判所でもらえますよ。
You can get the application form at the courthouse.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: コウイチ大統領は、報道陣と会見をする予定でしたが、食中毒にかかってしまったため中止となりました。
President Koichi was supposed to meet with the press corps, but he got food poisoning and it was canceled.

mnemonics.meaning: You tenaciously wear something. You have some kind of attachment to it. Some kind of tenacity that makes you obsessed with it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 異常なほどお金に執着する男の小説を書いてみたいんだよね。
I’d like to write a novel about a guy who has an abnormal obsession with money.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼が塁を踏んだのかどうか、よく見えなかった。
I couldn’t really see if he stepped on the base or not.

mnemonics.meaning: A baseball base judge is one who judges things on a baseball field. This is a baseball umpire, or more simply, an umpire.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの一塁の塁審、試合中に屁をこきまくってたぜ。
The umpire at first base kept farting during the game.

mnemonics.meaning: A baseball base hit is a base hit or single in baseball terms. A 二塁打 is a double, a 三塁打 is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

sentences: 彼が塁打を打つのは久しぶりだね。いつもはホームランだからな。
It’s been a long time since he made a base hit. He always hits homeruns.

mnemonics.meaning: A war struggle is the part in war where you have to struggle at each other. This is a battle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 実際のところ、忍者は直接戦闘することをできるだけ避けた。
Actually, ninjas tried to avoid combat as much as possible.

mnemonics.meaning: An explode bullet is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a bomb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 爆弾を分解することは危険だってことは分かってたんだけど、すごく興味があったんだ。
I knew taking apart the bomb could be very dangerous, but I was really interested.

mnemonics.meaning: An explode attack is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a bombing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そのチョコレート工場は、爆撃を受けて粉々になりました。
The chocolate factory crumbled to pieces from the bombing.

mnemonics.meaning: Your eyebrows interval is that place between your eyebrows called the brow. The technical term for this interval between your brows is the glabella, but I bet you never use that word. Unless you're... an eyebrow doctor?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but it uses the slightly less common けん reading for 間. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember: You stare at the beautiful brow on your Ken (けん) doll, completely mesmerized. You wish your brow looked as perfectly groomed as his... le sigh~

sentences: 社長は眉間にシワを寄せながら「この資料は誰が書いた？」と言った。
The company president said, "Who wrote these documents?" while furrowing his brow.
私のパグのチャームポイントはやはり眉間のシワです。
You know, my pug's most attractive feature is the lines on his brow after all.
眉間を黒いマジックで塗りつぶしてください。
Please fill in your brow with black marker.

mnemonics.meaning: Back in the day, a bullet was a circle shape. So, this word is bullet.
mnemonics.reading: The 弾 part is okay, but you never learned the on'yomi reading of 丸, which is がん. When you shoot a bullet, you are using a gun (がん). Bang!

sentences: 俺は弾丸の雨をとても上手くかわした。
I expertly dodged a spray of bullets.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Remember 球? This is also a bullet shape (remember how bullets used to be round spheres?). These are both similar ideas, though their intent is different, and they share the same reading.

sentences: 先日、銃の弾のようなかたちの便が出た。
My poop was shaped like a bullet for a gun the other day.

mnemonics.meaning: An army base is managed from the camp. This is where all the bigwigs get together, talk, and manage things, right over the open fire.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 敵の陣営が見えてくると、恐怖を感じ始めました。
Once the enemy camp came into view, I started to feel afraid.

mnemonics.meaning: I pledge myself to the machines. It is my only chance to survive the upcoming machine apocalypse.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 吐血したのを契機に、煙草を止めました。
Coughing up blood was my opportunity to give up smoking.

mnemonics.meaning: When something begins to crumble and break, it will certainly collapse at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今朝の俺のクソが大き過ぎて、トイレの床が崩壊したんだ。
My poop was so big this morning that the bathroom floor collapsed.

mnemonics.meaning: I pledge and promise to do that thing... so much so, I'm willing to sign a contract about it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの事件が先方に契約を解除させたんだよ。
That incident led them to cancel the contract.

mnemonics.meaning: A fire burial is when you burn the body. You call this cremation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 火葬のシステムは自動的に停止する訳ではありません。係の人が小窓から骨の様子を見ながら、終わったと思う時に止めるのです。
The cremation system doesn’t shut down automatically. The person in charge checks how the bones are doing from a small window once in a while and stops it when they think it’s done.

mnemonics.meaning: A death punishment is the death penalty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 死刑執行は五時間も遅れました。
The execution was delayed for five hours.

mnemonics.meaning: Whittle down and exclude this item from the list. Time to remove it. It's deletion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: インターネット上からあんたの写真を全部削除するのは、時間はかかるだろうけど、俺の手に掛かれば不可能じゃないね。
It’s gonna take some time to delete all your pictures off the Internet, but it’s not impossible for me.

mnemonics.meaning: The sect of dispatch helps with all the dispatch and deployment duties. When used together with the word 社員, this word can also mean temporary, in the sense of a temporary employee, possibly someone working for a company via a temping agency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本政府は被災地に医師団を派遣した。
The Japanese government dispatched a team of doctors to the area affected by the disaster.
アメリカ軍はイラクに軍を派遣した。
The American military deployed a unit to Iraq.
その派遣社員は、新しい職場の雰囲気をすぐに掴みました。
The temporary worker quickly got used to the atmosphere of her new office.

mnemonics.meaning: Time to pay over your drunkedness. You try, but you can't pay over drunkedness. You must be super drunk to think that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of 酔う and 払い, put together with some small っ and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.

sentences: 昨日の夜酔っ払いに絡まれた時、心臓がドキドキしました。
My heart was pounding while I was hassled by a drunk last night.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want the power to stop a bullet you need to have just the right amount of elasticity. Bullets go right through rigid things, but if the material is strong and has the right amount of flexibility, the bullet will bounce right off!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お肌の弾力が無くなってきているの。
The elasticity of my skin is disappearing.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who is so afflicted that you have to hurry and help is an emergency patient.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人員不足でごった返しになっていた病院が急患の受け入れを断ったせいで、男性が死亡したそうなんだけど、でもそれって病院だけのせいじゃないよね。
The understaffed and overcrowded hospital refused to treat the emergency patient and he died, but it’s not all the hospital’s fault.

mnemonics.meaning: Evidence traces are little bits of evidence, or proof, left behind. They're the traces that show that something happened.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 部屋には犯罪の証跡はなかったが、警察は殺人事件ではないかと考えていた。
Although there was no evidence of crime in the room, the police thought that it was a murder case.

mnemonics.meaning: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is exam hell.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 試験地獄に苦しむ日本の学生にとっては、電車で勉強するのは当たり前のことです。
Studying on the train is common for Japanese students who suffer from exam hell.

mnemonics.meaning: Explode departure is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an explosion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女の一言が彼の怒りを爆発させました。
Her words caused him to explode with anger.

mnemonics.meaning: Explode with laughs, what explosive laughter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 笑 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who has come down with explosive laughter? It's the shogun (しょう)! The shogun just can't stop laughing.

sentences: 母さんと父さんを爆笑させるような、何かいいエイプリルフールの案はある？
Do you have any good April fool’s ideas to make our parents explode with laughter?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. This also includes the place where your eyebrows live: your brow.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're staring lovingly at your own eyebrows in the mirror when your mom walks in and you gasp, "Ma! You... (まゆ)" but you're in so much shock you can't finish the sentence, "Ma, you shaved off your eyebrows?!"

sentences: 眉の形は人によって違う。
Eyebrow shape varies from person to person.
早く、眉にピアス開けたいな。
I want to get my eyebrow pierced soon.
眉の動きに注目すると表情を捉えやすいって知ってましたか？
Did you know paying attention to how eyebrows move makes it easier to perceive facial expressions?

mnemonics.meaning: You must struggle with intention. You know you're going to win this way. Show your fighting spirit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その戦闘ロボットは、メラメラと闘志を燃やしていた。
The battle robot was full of fighting spirit.

meanings: first ten days of the month

mnemonics.meaning: The above time of the month Is the top part of the month. The first ten days of the month, or the beginning of the month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 気象庁は六月上旬に梅雨が始まると言っている。
The Japan Meteorological Agency says the rainy season will start at the beginning of June.

mnemonics.meaning: A fishing expert is a fisherman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the りょう reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a fisherman.

sentences: 私はその漁師を知っていますよ。私の義理の兄ですから。
I know that fisherman because he is my brother in law.

mnemonics.meaning: A fishing boat is a fishing boat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨夜漁船を盗まれました。
I had my fishing boat stolen last night.

mnemonics.meaning: The fishing industry is the fishing industry or a fishery.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここは小さな漁村で、ここに住むほとんどの人は漁業に従事しています。
This is a small fishing village and most of the people living here are engaged in fishing.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, fragrance.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fragrance you smell is somebody's 顔 (かお). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!

sentences: どの香りを付けるかを決めるのは難しいですね。毎朝短くとも一時間はそれに時間を費やします。
It is hard to choose which perfume to wear. It takes me at least an hour every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: If you recruit gold you are trying to raise money, aka you are fundraising.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一万円札を崩してもらうことはできますか？もしそれができるなら、千円札を募金します。
Could you break a ten thousand yen bill? If you can I’ll donate a thousand yen to your fundraiser.

mnemonics.meaning: A burial ceremony is a funeral.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし誰かから電話があったら、葬式に出ていて三時に戻ると伝えてください。
If anyone calls, say I’m at a funeral and will be back at three o’clock.

mnemonics.meaning: A fueling (給油) place is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a gas station or a filling station.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この給油所ではどのくらい働いているんですか？
How long have you worked at this gas station?

mnemonics.meaning: A big resist is something he generally and usually does... at least in most cases. He's usually a big resistor, that one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大抵の外国人は納豆が苦手かと思いますが、私もその一人です。
I think most foreigners usually don’t like natto and I’m one of them.

mnemonics.meaning: Skewers you grill (焼く) turn into grilled skewers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings you already learned. You should be able to read it already!

sentences: 最近、ケールの串焼きにはまっています。
Lately, I've been into grilled kale skewers.
金曜日の夜は、串焼き屋さんで夕飯を食べました。
I had dinner at a grilled skewer place Friday night.
うちのインコは「串焼きにしないで！」が口癖です。
Our parakeet's catchphrase is, "Don't turn me into grilled skewers!"

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it contains some extra similar meanings as well, like a bay or inlet.
mnemonics.reading: Same reading as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 伯父は、殺されて、ドラム缶の中でコンクリート詰めにされて東京湾に沈められました。
My uncle was killed, put in a concrete drum filled with cement, and sunk in Tokyo Bay.

mnemonics.meaning: On the second day, you experience your drunkenness a different way... in the form of a hangover.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 二日 and 酔い put together (the reading for that comes from 酔う).

sentences: 二日酔いだし、足もつるし今日は最悪だよ。
I’m hungover and I also have a cramp in my leg. Today is the worst.

mnemonics.meaning: Your listen power is your hearing ability.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日の午後に、盲目の人の聴力に関するレポートを提出するつもりです。
I’m going to submit my report about blind people’s hearing abilities this afternoon.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that the kanji means hug and the verb 抱く means "to hug". This noun is similar, but it usually means carrying by hugging, so holding in one's arms or carrying. This is one that children use a lot!
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

sentences: 姉ちゃん、抱っこして！
Big sis, carry me!
娘は抱っこをしているとぐっすり寝てくれます。
My daughter sleeps soundly when I hold her in my arms.
友達の赤ちゃんのために、抱っこひもを選びました。
We chose a carrier for our friend's baby.

mnemonics.meaning: The fragrance harbor, perhaps this is where the perfumes came from back in the day. This place is Hong Kong.
mnemonics.reading: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to ほんこん. Almost the same, right?

sentences: 週の前半は出張で香港にいます。
I’ll be in Hong Kong at the start of the week for a business trip.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

sentences: 苺は旬ではありませんが、クリスマスケーキにたくさん使われます。
Although strawberries aren’t in season, they are used a lot for Christmas cake.

mnemonics.meaning: The punish task place is the place you go to do your task of punishment. It is a jail or prison.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この刑務所は今満員なので、キャンセル待ちとさせて頂きますね。
This prison is full at the moment, so we’ll put you on the waiting list.

mnemonics.meaning: The fragrance river prefecture is Kagawa Prefecture. Might help to look at the reading first.
mnemonics.reading: This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help: If you want to get to Kagawa Prefecture you're going to need a car (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!

sentences: フグ夫妻は二人とも香川県には住んでいるが、別居中です。
Both Mr. and Mrs. Fugu live in Kagawa prefecture, but they live apart from each other now.

meanings: last ten days of the month

mnemonics.meaning: The below time of month is the bottom part of the month. It's the last ten days of the month, aka the end of the month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 四月の下旬に日本に戻って、六月上旬にまたアメリカに戻ってくる予定です。
I’m planning to go back to Japan at the end of April and come back to the states at the beginning of June.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how a 年賀状 is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (紹介), making it a letter of introduction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 紹介 as well.

sentences: この病院で予約をするには、お医者さんからの紹介状が要ります。
You need a referral letter from a doctor to make an appointment at this hospital.

mnemonics.meaning: Until the end of somebody, you will be punished. If you are punished to your end, you are being given a life sentence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 終身刑を言い渡されたのは初めてです。
This is the first time I’ve been given a life sentence.

mnemonics.meaning: A listen someone, is someone who listens. This is a listener.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. For this word, most often you'll hear the word リスナー but this is a kanji learning site, so you're going to be learning yourself some kanji, you hear?

sentences: 電話が壊れてるのかも。だって、聴者から電話が一本もないなんて、おかしいよ。
Something might be wrong with the phone because it’s weird that no listeners have called in.

mnemonics.meaning: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as 一人, means you are living alone.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab readings from 一人 and 暮らす.

sentences: 一人暮らしをしているので、冬時間が始まった時に、時計を一時間遅らせることを忘れてしまいました。
I’m living alone and I forgot to set my clock back an hour when the winter time started.

meanings: middle ten days of the month

mnemonics.meaning: The middle time of the month is the middle ten days of the month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 予定日は十一月の中旬です。
My due day is around the middle of November.

mnemonics.meaning: Some odd traces are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a miracle, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 奇跡でも起こらない限り、百人が同時におならをするのは不可能でしょう。
Unless there is a miracle, a hundred people won’t be able to fart at the same time.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 味噌 is "miso," and that 汁 is "soup." So, combine them together and you have Miso Soup.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 味噌 plus the vocab 汁 put together.

sentences: 「明日までに、この味噌汁を飲んでしまわなければならないよ。」「じゃあ、さっさと片付けちまおうぜ。」
"We have to finish eating this miso soup by tomorrow." "Okay, let’s get it over with."

mnemonics.meaning: To display and indicate something is to put up a notice or bulletin.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アヤは、レストランが臨時休業の掲示をしている紙に余白があるのを見つけては、そこに落書きをします。
Whenever Aya sees that a restaurant put up a notice about shutting down for a holiday and there is some space left on the paper, she draws doodles there.

mnemonics.meaning: An oil painting is an oil painting.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi for 油 (which you learned with the vocabulary) and the on'yomi for 絵 (which you learned with the kanji).

sentences: この油絵はフリマで千五百円で買ったんですよ。
I bought this oil painting for 1500 yen at a flea market.
祖母は油絵を集めていた。
My grandmother used to collect oil paintings.
油絵用の絵の具で有名なブランドは？
What's the most famous brand of oil paints?

mnemonics.meaning: A before omen is something that tells you about something that will happen before it happens. Really this is just an omen or sign.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この雲と風は嵐の前兆です。
The clouds and wind are signs of a storm.

mnemonics.meaning: The pay that supports you is made in payments. Whether you make payments to keep your house or your car, or you get payments from your boss, they keep you going.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 支 and the kun'yomi reading of 払. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

sentences: 支払いはカードでお願いします。
Please make payments by card.

mnemonics.meaning: If 払う is "to pay" then the noun version is a payment.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 払う, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one.

sentences: 現金払いにして頂けるなら、5%引きにさせて頂きます。
We offer 5% off if you pay with cash.

mnemonics.meaning: A fragrance of water is a perfume.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 学校では香水が禁止されているにもかかわらず、その男子生徒はいつも甘い香りの香水を付けていて、教師たちには自然な脇の臭いだと言っていた。
Even though wearing perfume is banned at school, that guy always wears a fragrant perfume and he told the teachers that it was his natural armpit smell.

mnemonics.meaning: A punish action is when someone goes out to try to find people who do bad things, so that they can be punished. The people who do this are people like a police detective (or detective).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その刑事は俺の彼女の腕を突然掴んで、彼女にキスをしたんだ。だから、俺はそいつを殴りつけてやったんだけど、そしたら逮捕されたんだよ。そんなの不公平だよ。
Without warning that officer grabbed my girlfriend’s arm and kissed her. So I punched him and he arrested me. It’s unfair.

mnemonics.meaning: A ____pot is any kind of food that's made inside the pot, put together, and cooked. This refers to a type of pot, stew or hotpot, and is attached onto the names of said pots, stews, and hotpots.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 豆乳鍋を食べてみたことはありますか？
Have you ever tried soy milk hotpot?

mnemonics.meaning: A punish period of time is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your prison term.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その囚人は、十五年間の刑期を務めた後で釈放されたが、行く当てがなかった。
The convict was released after serving a fifteen-year prison term, but he had nowhere to go.

mnemonics.meaning: Display and publish your writing into a publication or form of print.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグに掲載されているブログ記事を何部かコピーして、日本語を学習している私の生徒たちに配っても構いませんか？
Do you mind if I reproduce some copies of articles published on Tofugu and distribute them to my students who are studying Japanese?

mnemonics.meaning: A punish penalty is a punishment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 犯罪を根絶するには、火あぶりの刑みたいな残酷な刑罰を全部復活させるべきだと思うね。
In order to root out crime, I think we should restore all the brutal punishments, like burning people at the stake.

mnemonics.meaning: I want to recruit some people, so let's gather them up and do some recruiting and solicitation to get them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグはまだブロガーを募集中ですよ。
Tofugu is still recruiting bloggers.

mnemonics.meaning: Whittle down and decrease something. This is a reduction or cutback, since you're whittling down and decreasing it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コストの削減に苦戦しています。
I’ll have a hard time reducing the cost.

mnemonics.meaning: My dialect has offended you? I will make reparation by giving you a reimbursement and some compensation. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 撮影中に漁師さんの網を誤って破いてしまったため、弁償しなくてはならなかった。
I ripped a fisherman’s nets by mistake while taking pictures, so I had to reimburse him.

mnemonics.meaning: We are ready to confront war, if we have to. We are going to start the resistance against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 学生たちは、権威に対して徹底抗戦を強いられました。
The students were forced to resist to the bitter end against authority.

mnemonics.meaning: All you leave behind are traces of the past. These are the ruins of what happened before. The historic remains...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 古代の遺跡で、フグの形をした石像を見つけました。
We found a Fugu-shaped stone statue in the ancient ruins.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're boat drunk you have sea sickness.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 船 goes to ふな (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The 酔い comes from 酔う.

sentences: この薬で船酔いを克服しました。
I got over my seasickness with this medicine.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look to the sea, you are seaside or coastal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本の学生の多くは、夏に臨海学校に行く事を経験します。
Many Japanese students experience going to seaside schools during the summer.

mnemonics.meaning: A one's self (自己) introduction (紹介) is a self introduction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自己紹介では、いつもすぐ言うことがなくなっちゃうんだよね。
Whenever I introduce myself, I quickly run out of things to say.

mnemonics.meaning: 恥 is a "disgrace." If you 知らず then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a shameless person, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 恥 and 知る put together.

sentences: あの俺の兄貴は恥知らずの嘘つきだ。何の事だかサッパリ分からないなんて言ってたくせに、俺のベーコンを平らげたのはアイツだったんだよ。
My brother is such a shameless liar. He told me he had no idea what happened, but he was the one who ate all my bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: A he woman is she. Also could mean girlfriend, depending on how it's used.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the 彼 portion. Just think about how she (your girlfriend) is a canoe (かの), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.

sentences: 彼女は服のセンスはいいが、体型がいまいちだ。
She has good taste in clothes, but she doesn’t have the best figure.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have to aim with your attack, you're probably shooting or sniping something with a projectile (like a gun, or something).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 男は政治家を狙撃するために、そのホテルの部屋が見える場所までやってきた。
He positioned himself in view of the hotel room to snipe the politician.

mnemonics.meaning: The shining peace time was a time known as the Showa Era. This can also refer to the Showa Emperor or just Showa itself. Everything Showa is here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昭和何年生まれですか。
Which year of Showa were you born in?

mnemonics.meaning: An omen for the climate of things is a sign or indication of change. If there's an omen, there's going to be a sign as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は、私に下痢の兆候がきたと告げるやいなや、トイレに駆け込んでいった。
She told me that she had symptoms of diarrhea and rushed into the bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: 今度のBBQには100本くらい串が必要です。
We need about a hundred skewers for the BBQ that's coming up.
肉とジャガイモに串を刺してくれませんか？
Could you skewer the meat and potatoes?
焼き鳥とは、串に刺さった鶏肉のことです。
Yakitori is chicken spitted on skewers.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of slow? It's slow (or, if you're slow, you're probably late, too).
mnemonics.reading: How slow are you? You are oh so slow (おそ).

sentences: 私のパソコンはハードディスクの容量が無くなってきているので、動作がすごく遅いです。
My computer is very slow because it’s running out of hard drive space.

mnemonics.meaning: A soup thing is what you use to refer to soups.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word 汁.

sentences: あいつ、あのウェイトレスさんに三回もこのレストランに汁物はないのかって聞きやがったんだぜ。ウェイトレスさんその度にありませんって言ってさ、困惑してたよ。
He asked the waitress three times if there was any soup in the restaurant and she answered no each time. She was bewildered.

mnemonics.meaning: If you self explode, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a suicide bomb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今月末までに、自爆テロを実行しなくてはなりません。
I have to commit a suicide bombing by the end of this month.

mnemonics.meaning: Sweet vinegar is sweet vinegar. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 甘い plus 酢, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the す to ず so, remember that.

sentences: この間、給食の時に生徒が何故か机の中から甘酢の瓶を取り出したのよ。
During lunch the other day for some reason one of the students pulled a bottle of sweet vinegar out of her desk.

mnemonics.meaning: The machine gulf isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents Taiwan.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is たい for 台, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The わん is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to だいわん, you'll probably realize that this is たいわん.

sentences: 感染源を台湾のアヒルの群れだと突き止めました。
We’ve traced the source of the infection and it was a flock of ducks in Taiwan.

mnemonics.meaning: Look to time to see how much longer this will last. It's not forever, it's temporary, which is why we must look to time to figure out how much longer it'll be around.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: マミは、臨時のボーナスが出たので、さらにベーコンを購入した。
Mami got an extra bonus, so she bought more bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is recruit so the verb vocab version would, you'd think, be 'to recruit,' but it's to appeal for something or to invite something or to raise something. So, it's kind of like recruiting, but instead of people, you're recruiting for things and actions. This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean to grow violent or to become stronger. It's like all of that recruiting is happening inside of you and causing some weird things to happen to you!
mnemonics.reading: You'd like to appeal for two, no (つの), three things! Three!

sentences: 妻への不信感は募るばかりです。
My distrust for my wife is only growing stronger.
みんなで募金を募りましょう。
Let's all appeal for funding together!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means afflicted and the verb vocab version is to be afflicted.
mnemonics.reading: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I was a Ra (わずら), but now I'm just me again.

sentences: シェルターには、結核を患うホームレスの人がたくさんいます。
In the shelter there are many homeless people sick with tuberculosis.

mnemonics.meaning: 恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is to be shy or to be bashful.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 恥ずかしい.

sentences: ストリッパーになると自分で決断したにも関わらず、彼女はまだ人前で裸で踊ることを恥ずかしがっているんだよ。
Although she was determined to become a stripper, she’s still shy about dancing naked in public.

mnemonics.meaning: Weird that this kanji means bullet but the verb vocab version means to bounce. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going to bounce.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to bounce something off that wall, it has (はず) to be made of rubber, otherwise it will just go right through. It has to.

sentences: ボールが地面を弾んでに湖に落ちた。
The ball bounced off the ground and fell into the lake.
飼い主の大きいお腹の上で無じゃ気に弾んでいる猫の動画にいやされています。
I am soothed by this video of a cat bouncing absentmindedly on its owner's large belly.
彼との会話がこんなに弾むなんて、思ってもみなかったわ。
I never expected such a lively conversation between the two of us.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burial, so the verb version would be to bury or to inter.
mnemonics.reading: We're going to bury you, so this is your new home (ほうむ) now, friend.

sentences: その事件の真相が闇に葬られるのではないかと心配しています。
I’m worried that the truth of the incident might be buried.

mnemonics.meaning: To make reparation is to compensate for or to make up for. Take responsibility for your actions and make up for everything.
mnemonics.reading: When you go to compensate for what you did, you become too good for your own britches. You are too good now (つぐなう).

sentences: たとえあなたが死をもって罪を償っても、問題は解決しないでしょう。
Even if you atoned for your sins with your own death, it wouldn’t solve the problem.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means dispatch but this word is to consider or to make use of. Just think about how if you have people that are on dispatch for you, you can send them information to consider and to make use of.
mnemonics.reading: This has a similar meaning to 使う, and has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.

sentences: 義理の両親と暮らすのって、毎日気を遣うだろうし、疲れちゃうと思うのよね。
I think living with my in-laws would mean I’d have to take care of them every day, and I’d get worn out.

mnemonics.meaning: We are versus yonder (that side). We need to switch things around on that side, and we need to counter them now that it's our turn.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 対向するバイクの存在を完璧に見落としていました。
I completely failed to see the oncoming motorcycle.
対向する車に向かって手を振りました。
I waved at the oncoming car.
対向する車がいないからって、明るい道でハイビームで走るなよ。対向する歩行者の身になれよな。
Don't drive on high beams on a well-lit street just because there are no oncoming cars. Think about oncoming pedestrians.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is crumble, so what happens when you crumble something? You are going to demolish it. You are going to break it. You know you're doing the crumbling / demolishing because someone's going to sue (す) you for what you've done here today.
mnemonics.reading: You are Zeus, and you demolish everything in your path. Your friend Hercules watches and is all like "That's coo' Zeus (くず), that's so cool."

sentences: 「1ドル札を崩してもらえませんか？」「ええっと…25セント硬貨が2枚と10セント硬貨が5枚あります。これでよろしいですか？」「はい。有難うございます。」
"Do you have change for a dollar?" "Let me see. I have two quarters and five dimes. Is this good?" "Yup, thanks."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means favor and the verb vocab version is to do a favor for.
mnemonics.reading: If you are going to do a favor for anyone, it's going to be for your good buddy meg (めぐ). Imagine a Meg you know (or know of) and imagine yourself doing a favor for her. Meg Ryan is so happy you're in her life.

sentences: 本日のトーフグの収益の全額が、恵まれない子どもたちに寄付されます。
All of Tofugu’s proceeds from today will be donated to underprivileged children.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look to something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is to face, as in "to face terrorism," etc.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you must (to) face terrorism is because the terrorists have threatened to take everyone's noses (のぞ) away. We must face them head on if we are to save our noses!

sentences: トーフグの本社は、オレゴン州という、太平洋に臨むアメリカ北西部の州に位置しています。
The Tofugu headquarters is located in Oregon, which is a state in the northwestern United States facing the Pacific.

mnemonics.meaning: If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is to get torn or to get broken or to get ripped.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 破る.

sentences: ズボンのお尻の部分がいつも最初に破れるんだけど、どうしてだろう。
Why do my pants always start wearing out in the butt area first?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hug and the verb vocab version is to hug or to embrace. 抱いて抱いて！
mnemonics.reading: What are you going to hug? How about a cute duck (だく), or even just your dad (だ). Duckを抱く?

sentences: 母熊は自分の赤ん坊を抱き上げ、顔中を舐め回した。
The mother bear embraced her baby and licked it all over its face.

mnemonics.meaning: A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is to introduce.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

sentences: お前にどの娘を紹介するかを選ぶのは難しいよ。
It’s hard to choose which girl to introduce to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hop and the verb vocab version is to hop or to jump or to leap. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
mnemonics.reading: Know how 飛ぶ means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

sentences: 彼女は完璧なトリプルアクセルを跳んだのに、スコアはあまり伸びなかった。
She performed a perfect triple axel, but her score wasn’t very good.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means listen and the verb vocab version is to listen to or to hear.
mnemonics.reading: The meaning is really similar to 聞く, right? The reading is the same.

sentences: その癒し系の曲を聴いてると、眠くなってきたよ。
I’m listening to this relaxing song and I’m getting sleepy.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means display, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going to put up something, or, sometimes more specifically, to put up a sign.
mnemonics.reading: You have to put up a sign for your newest invention, the car car (かか). It is a car made so that other cars can drive the car. Nobody wants to buy it, which is why you have to put up a sign.

sentences: ジェームズは、鉛筆削りの技術のレベルを上げるという目標を掲げた。
James set a new goal: to bring his pencil sharpening to the next level.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're anti something and you confront the government about it, in some cases you are going to rebel against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 犬が私に反抗したので、「お前は悪い犬だ！」って叱りつけてやりましたよ。
The dog was hostile towards me, so I screamed at him, "You are a bad dog!"

mnemonics.meaning: Resist and confront those who oppose you. This is to resist.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてあのケーキを食べるのを抵抗したんだ？
Why did you resist eating the cake?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to be returned. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 母親が病気になったので、私は国に戻ることにしました。
I decided to return to my country because my mother got sick.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means struggle so the verb version is to struggle or to fight. This struggle is fairly figurative, too. It's more like "the struggle against terrorism" or "the fight against drugs." Not so much a fight with people, which would be 戦う.
mnemonics.reading: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "ta ta, car (たたか). Ta ta."

sentences: この子たちは、みんな病気と闘っているんです。
These kids are all fighting against their diseases.

mnemonics.meaning: 盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going to get excited. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 盛り and 上がる. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

sentences: 子どもっていうのは、どんなささいなことでも手当たり次第に盛り上がることができるのよね。
Kids can take the most mundane, random things and get so excited.

mnemonics.meaning: If you are tenacious you will be able to take control of and to carry out any plan you want. You are tenacious, you are.
mnemonics.reading: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say 取る. This word shares take's reading.

sentences: あなたにこのプロジェクトの指揮を執ってもらいたいんです。
We want you to direct this project.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means whittle down and the verb vocab version is to whittle something down, to shave something down, and to reduce something. This verb is transitive, meaning you're whittling something down, like a piece of wood, or reducing something, like your expenses.
mnemonics.reading: To whittle something down or not to whittle something down. Will have to take it on a case (けず) by case basis.

sentences: 木の枝を削ってはしを作りました。
I whittled down a tree branch to make chopsticks.
プロジェクトリーダーに予算を削られて備品が買えない。
The project leader reduced my budget and I can't buy any equipment.
歯を削る音ってのは、私にとっては最も不快な音の一つだね。
The sound of shaving down teeth is one of the most unpleasant sounds to me.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When something leaves traces or marks behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come 後 (あと) they left.

sentences: 私は、ワイングラスに付いた彼女の唇の跡を指でなぞった。
Her lips left marks on the wine glass and I traced it with my finger.

mnemonics.meaning: I steal by listening to what people say. I do this by wiretapping their phone and bugging their homes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰かがトーフグのオフィスに盗聴器を仕掛けたのですが、私達は犯人も理由も分かりません。
Someone bugged the Tofugu office, but we have no idea who or why.

mnemonics.meaning: You are favored with knowing things. You have wisdom and intelligence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 無い知恵を絞ってこのラブレターを書いたよ。
I racked my brain to write this love letter.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a tenacious writing brush, you are doing a lot of writing. Also, if you write for a magazine you probably write a ton too, because they have to come out with new issues every week or month.
mnemonics.reading: The 執 is a little altered, where しつ is shortened to しっ. You've seen this kind of thing before, so just keep this shortening pattern in mind and you'll be a-okay!

sentences: 最後に短編小説を執筆したのはいつですか？
When was the last time you wrote a short story?

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means have.
You see something with a flag on it and put it in your mouth. It was spicy! You look at the little flag and it says... hot pepper.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means prefecture.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means sky.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means think.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means tooth.

A leader asks half of his men to accompany him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him. Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
mnemonics.reading: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome. Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.

mnemonics.meaning: You get tooth orders. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your age. You get baby age tooth orders (to get your first teeth). You get child age tooth orders (to get your adult teeth). Then you get old age tooth orders (when you start losing your teeth). There are tooth orders for every age.
mnemonics.reading: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun. Decide what age you have to be to get your first ray gun, and then imagine getting it when you hit that age. Perhaps you use this ray gun on your teeth, to keep them clean. Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: By showing the roof of your top hat you send your best regards. Giving your best regards is basically just tipping your hat and showing the roof of it.
mnemonics.reading: When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person. YOLO means "you only live once," so in a way that's a good way to give your best regards. At the very least, it's an interesting way.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth has a tooth that you use to bite and chew with. Imagine that one tooth in your mouth chewing through everything. It's not easy to chew with only one tooth, but luckily yours is huge and razor-sharp, so it helps you to bite and chew your way through anything you like.
mnemonics.reading: Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to bite and chew up a whole  car (か). Some people like eating cars, and you're one of them. You can't get enough of those delicious cars. You just bite them apart and chew.

mnemonics.meaning: The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood. Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
mnemonics.reading: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?! Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything? And you counter with. Why not?

mnemonics.meaning: Someone is offering you a shellfish in exchange for a kiss. This is a bribe! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty. "Come on, don't you want this shellfish?" they ask, shaking it up and down at you.
mnemonics.reading: You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!! This is why you never accept a bribe. One second you're staring a yummy shellfish in the face, and the next you're standing alone in the road feeling used.

mnemonics.meaning: The door in that direction is among a cluster of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it. Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
mnemonics.reading: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly! Watch as clusters of pins fall when the bowling balls hit them. You back up and peek through one of the other doors in the cluster and it also houses a bowling alley. Huh.

mnemonics.meaning: A tiger needs to think and consider its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation. Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. You need to consider how you’re going to escape from this tiger.
mnemonics.reading: It's considering you for so long that it takes out a robe (りょ), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think. Consider this! Tigers look great in robes.

mnemonics.meaning: They say if you put things on a slide, seven things to be exact, that’s the best way to consign goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em. Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
mnemonics.reading: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt. Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Past stamps usually depict images contrary to current views. Look at this stamp. There's Columbus being hugged by a bunch of South American natives. Yikes, that's contrary to how things went, that's for sure.
mnemonics.reading: Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people. Be contrary to the evildoers of the past and be like Kyaku instead.

mnemonics.meaning: In the rain I take my rake and shake it, making a demand that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it! Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
mnemonics.reading: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.  Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.

mnemonics.meaning: You offer a hot pepper to the king, and he gives you a drop of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a disc. And not just any old disc at that. It's a jade disc. Have you ever seen ancient Chinese jade discs with holes in the middle? That's what this kanji is referring to. You took a long time to pick out the perfect hot pepper. Only the best for the king, right? It burned your hands a little as you held it on your way to the palace. You were hoping for something pretty special in return, but you never imagined it would be a drop that magically turns into a disc. Wow!
mnemonics.reading: Wait, did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on? You start to realize just how crazy the situation is. Seriously. How the heck is a drop able to turn into a jade disc?

mnemonics.meaning: A mole in winter will do whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it. They do most of their own chores during the rest of the year, so winter is when you should ask them to do things for you.
mnemonics.reading: To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち). Moles will do anything for cheese, but honestly, wouldn't we all?

mnemonics.meaning: You're on a scooter and suddenly someone throws a hot pepper at you and you have to dodge it. Imagine riding your scooter, dodging multiple hot peppers as they're tossed at you. A few of them get stuck in the wheels and keep coming around and around, and you have to dodge them too.
mnemonics.reading: As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating. Feel the heat flow through your body. It's getting harder to dodge as the heat grows and you start sweating!

mnemonics.meaning: When you see flowers in a rice paddy you can't help but use your fingers to draw them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone. Imagine using your fingers to draw these rice paddy flowers. Don't worry about how well you can draw, this is so beautiful, anyone could capture it.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O. To be fair, would you want to look at a drawing that makes you constantly smell stinky B.O.? I didn't think so.

mnemonics.meaning: You got your copy of "The Dry Knife." It's the newest edition of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry. You're really into this magazine, and when you heard there's a new edition of it, you went out and bought it right away.
mnemonics.reading: In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning. The article on Genghis Khan was perhaps the best written article in the Dry Knife series to date. How did this magazine get such a big interview?

mnemonics.meaning: You use your scooter when the omen comes so that you can escape. Unfortunately, the omen is riding a scooter too, so you're going to have to be crafty to escape this omen properly.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way. Imagine scooting in and out of とうきょう traffic, the omen looming ever further back behind you. You're doing it! You're escaping!

mnemonics.meaning: Where do you put your fingers when you're on an escalator? On the handle! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead. Imagine being on an escalator and wrapping your fingers around a small handle on your way up or down. It's still a bit precarious, truth be told.
mnemonics.reading: You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him. 暑か? Is the handle hot? Think about it. Is it? What does your imagination tell you?

mnemonics.meaning: If there’s a drop on your head and the rice is big, you know you’re in the interior. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
mnemonics.reading: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!” If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader with horns takes a lantern and searches for people to join him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern. Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
mnemonics.reading: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him. The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the moon beneath a tree there is a hat filled with water. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your knee in it. Feel the water splash over your knee as you stick it into this hat. It fits really well, the hat is the perfect size for your knee. Now look up at the moonlight filtering through the tree above.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hat water!! Imagine the heat then the zap going through your knee. It isn't a nice heat, it's a hot heat, then BZZZT zap! Your knee was heat zapped pretty bad.

mnemonics.meaning: You change this geoduck because you want it to lean. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.  Why do you want this geoduck to lean? Try to come up with your own reason. And why don't you look up what a geoduck looks like one more time for good measure. You don't want to be able to get this image out of your head.
mnemonics.reading: To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides. Watch as the geoduck slowly leans toward the cake, trying to get at it for a taste. But don't let it eat any! Keep putting the cake further and further away so the geoduck has to lean more.

mnemonics.meaning: The thread on this football is loose. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing. Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
mnemonics.reading: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man! Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.

mnemonics.meaning: When it's spring in heaven they play music. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up. Close your eyes and imagine all of the spring sounds that come down to you from heaven in the springtime. Mmm, you can almost smell the damp soil and rain.
mnemonics.reading: In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band! Picture all of the souls in heaven playing spring music together!

mnemonics.meaning: A woman who has a landslide getting ready inside her is pregnant. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide. Picture an ultrasound of the pregnant woman, but instead of a little baby heartbeat, you hear a scary roaring sound. That's what being pregnant is like. Waiting for the landslide to come.
mnemonics.reading: When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you. Imagine being pregnant and getting kicked by the shins of your baby all day, but especially all night. You're so tired. Please let this landslide come already.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman sleeps with the king and becomes pregnant. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby! The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
mnemonics.reading: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore. What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.

mnemonics.meaning: You put on the shellfish mask once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind presents. You're like beach santa, except you're real and you wear a mask made of shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses. Ooh hoo, it's me! the Shellfish Mask Man! I go to beach houses and leave presents where I can! The presents are not clothes, or anything good. I don't even care if you leave me some food. Try whipping some up, try cooking me peas, It matters not, I'll leave you zombies! Tee hee hee hee hee!

mnemonics.meaning: Shove your fingers into a bowl of shrimp to select the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most. Feel your fingers touching each and every shrimp, one by one, until they graze the one you select as the perfect shrimp. Slowly pull it out and lower it into your mouth. Munch munch... ahhh! The perfect shrimp.
mnemonics.reading: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)! Oh, woe is me! How will I select the perfect shrimp with my fingers if there are tacks in the shrimp bowls! Boohoohoo!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a scooter coming toward you with a net trapping a weird zombie on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to send back the zombie. You want to send back this zombie the way it came. You definitely don't want it loose in your neighborhood.
mnemonics.reading: As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came! You managed to send back the zombie, good for you! Genghis Khan would be proud.
