mnemonics.meaning: You have thread and some syrup and you need to spin them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head. Imagine carefully dripping syrup onto a thread and then spinning it in a circle.
mnemonics.reading: As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air. Imagine eating a syrup cookie you made by spinning it yourself. Homemade is always better than store-bought.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your fingers on the cat pirate to suppress him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you. Imagine suppressing a cat pirate with your own fingers. His fur is so soft, but his nails are so sharp!
mnemonics.reading: He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force. Defend the yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you suppress the cat pirate. Maybe even share the yolk with him, once he's done trying to kill you for it. And then enjoy breakfast while petting your new cat friend.

mnemonics.meaning: In your prefecture, you come from a long lineage of people who share one heart. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and suspends itself in the sky, for you to take. You see the suspended heart in the distance, and make your way towards it.
mnemonics.reading: You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai.  "I've protected this suspended heart for you, for you are next in the lineage to receive it." He grabs the heart and throws it into your body.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a grain and fashion it into a gun that is small, earning you the title of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations! This isn't exactly a title you're proud of, in fact, you're really embarrassed. Maybe you can make a name for yourself in something else so you can get a new title.
mnemonics.reading: Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it. The plaque says, "No one is more deserving of this SAD title." - Love, the Shougun.

mnemonics.meaning: You thread someone together with thread. Someone is falling apart so you use thread to put them back together. Imagine taking some thread and putting someone back together with it. It’s awfully messy. I hope you’re good with blood.
mnemonics.reading: You’re threading this someone back together as part of a show (しょ). The show is a demonstration to show med students how to thread someone’s skin together after they have an accident. You’re the most experienced, so you’re leading the show. Imagine threading someone back together again, but this time you have an audience. Hear them “ooh” and “aah” as you put on a riveting show.

mnemonics.meaning: Your boat holds your weapon like a plate. So in a way, it's just a tray for your weapon. A big boat shaped like a plate is just a tray. You keep your weapons on it, nice and flat.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, this boat tray is so big and flat that it keeps reflecting the light into your eyes, so you have to put on a pair of big Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. Picture yourself wearing your Ray-Bans as you look at your tray boat. The steel of your weapons reflect a lot of light into your eyes too. That's why you're wearing Ray-Bans.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 馬鹿 means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely absurd. Remember how ridiculous that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.
mnemonics.reading: You already learned 馬鹿, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!

sentences: 馬鹿馬鹿しいこと言わないでよ。
Don’t say stupid things.

mnemonics.meaning: 馬鹿 is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (らしい) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's absurd."
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 馬鹿.

sentences: 全く馬鹿らしいにもほどがある！！！
That’s completely absurd!!!

mnemonics.meaning: To 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is a favor or a request.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 頼む.

sentences: コウイチはビエトに窓を開けるよう頼みましたが、ビエトはコウイチの頼みを拒絶しました。
Koichi asked Viet to open the window, but Viet turned down Koichi's request.

mnemonics.meaning: A cool cluster is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is air conditioning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 暑すぎだよ〜。ちょっと冷房付けてもらえないかな。
It's too hot. Could you turn on the air conditioning please?

mnemonics.meaning: To 及ぶ is "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "as well as." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why "as well as" is the meaning of this one.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that one you know that one as well as this one.

sentences: このセキュリティー対策アプリは、AndroidOS及びiOSのどちらでもご利用頂けます。
This security app is for Android OS as well as iOS.

mnemonics.meaning: A dancing (舞踏) meet is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a ball or dance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今回の舞踏会には、前回よりも明るい色のドレスを着て行くつもりです。
For this dance, I’m thinking of wearing a brighter color dress than the last time.

mnemonics.meaning: A foundation tray is a flat thing that is your foundation. It holds everything up. It is the base of everything that goes above it. It is the foundation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ベーコン事業に先立ち、まずは資金基盤を築くつもりです。
We are going to build a fund base for the bacon business first.

mnemonics.meaning: You accept and consign the job. You are going to be entrusted with this property for the winter. Don't go into room 237.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我が社にとってその受託契約を受注することがどんなに重要か、分かっているよな。
Do you know how desperately we need the brokerage contract?

mnemonics.meaning: I dodged being pregnant. Whew. Good thing I was taking my birth control.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今年の新年の抱負の一つは、ちゃんと避妊をすること、です。
One of my New Year’s resolutions is to properly use contraception.

mnemonics.meaning: 豆腐 is tofu, and 湯 means hot water, making it tofu you've put in hot water, aka boiled tofu.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of 豆腐 and the kun'yomi reading of 湯. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 豆腐 as well.

sentences: 最初は、どんなもんかなと思って湯豆腐を食べてみただけなんですが、そしたら好きになっちゃったんですよね。
At first, I just tried the boiled tofu out of curiosity, and then I grew to like it.

mnemonics.meaning: A bribe bribe is a bribe.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼にはビッグマック以外の賄賂は効かないよ。
It’s impossible to bribe him with anything other than a Big Mac.

mnemonics.meaning: The presents you acquire are a bribe. What? That is bribery!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父は、私が三歳の時に、「その贈収賄事件には私は関与していない」と母に言うように教えた。
When I was three my father taught me to say, "I have nothing to do with the bribery case," to my mother.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 依頼 means "request." What's a "request" person? It's someone who requests things from you. In other words, your client!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もう少し我慢すれば、依頼人が誰だか分かったのに。
If you had a little more patience, you could have found out who the client was.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: "How many things are in this cluster?" asks your boss. "Just a few sah," (ふさ) you reply.

sentences: このブドウ、三房で298円だったんですよ。
These grapes were 298 yen for three bunches.
最近、房子は房飾りを中国から輸入してフリマで売っているらしいよ。
Recently, I heard that Fusako is importing tassels from China and selling them at flea markets.
「一房の髪」という小説に熱中しすぎていて、お気に入りのカバンをどこかに落としてしまったことに気が付かなかった。
I was so engrossed in the novel "A Tuft of Hair" that I didn't notice that I had dropped my favorite bag somewhere.

mnemonics.meaning: I'll think and consider this. I'll give it consideration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の家族ではなく自分の家族のことを考慮してください。
Please consider your own family instead of mine.

mnemonics.meaning: If you distribute your considers, you will be giving consideration and care to whatever you're distributing these cares to.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お母さん、大人って子供への配慮が欠けていると思わない？
Mom, don’t you think that adults lack consideration for kids?

mnemonics.meaning: To the committee I would like to consign these things. This is what I consign.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そいつがさ、男の目隠しまではしたけど、残りの殺人業務は他の暗殺者に委託したって言うんだよ。
He says that he did blindfold the guy, but entrusted the rest of the murder to the other assassin.

mnemonics.meaning: Try to suppress and control the enemy. We must control them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生理前は、月経前症候群のせいで、感情をうまく抑制することができません。
I can’t control my emotions well before my period because of PMS.

mnemonics.meaning: The day's edition is the daily edition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The にち goes to にっ.

sentences: アヤが描いたパグのイラストが、ある日刊紙のマスコットキャラクターに選ばれました。
Aya’s illustration of the cute pug was selected as a daily newspaper’s mascot character.

mnemonics.meaning: You demand and need this thing, which is why you must make this demand.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグTシャツは需要は大きいかもしれないけど、コスパがあまり良くないんだよね。
Tofugu t-shirts may be in high demand, but their cost performance isn’t great.

mnemonics.meaning: Draw a copy of the world and you are making a depiction of the world.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アヤは、トーフグ殺人事件を細部に渡って描写した。
Aya drew a detailed depiction of the Tofugu murder case.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is in the interior AND the bottom? Why, it's in the very depths! And if it's in the interior and bottom of you, then it's at the bottom of your heart!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 心の奥底でほくそ笑みました。
I chuckled from the depths of my heart.

mnemonics.meaning: This is going to suppress and stop what's coming at you. It's a deterrent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どの国が一番素晴らしい犯罪抑止モデルを有していると思われますか。
Which country do you think has the best crime prevention model?

mnemonics.meaning: A round tray is a disk, though if it goes through the air it becomes a flying saucer.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: しばらくすると、ジェームズは円盤を脇に抱えて戻ってきて、UFOを見つけたんだと言いました。
After a while, James came back with a disk under his arm and told us he found a UFO.

mnemonics.meaning: A join kill is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a double play.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「ゲッツー」というのは、併殺を意味する和製英語です。
"Get two" is a Japanese word derived from English meaning double play.

mnemonics.meaning: If you draw a drawing or painting, you will end up with a drawing or painting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: クロード・モネは、点画法という、点描画法とは少し違った技法を得意としていました。
Claude Monet was very good at stippling, which is a bit different from pointillism.

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and suspend fate, let's get this done before the time we are fated to do it. We are that eager to get started.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 足が泥にはまって、一生懸命抜こうとしてみたんですが、できなかったんです。
My foot was stuck in the mud and I tried with all my might to get it out, but I couldn’t.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone of tall age is going to be an elderly person or an old person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 高齢者たちは、雇用について難しい問題を抱えています。
Elderly people have difficult problems with employment.

mnemonics.meaning: If you escape death you have, well, an escape.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の弟は優し過ぎて犯罪者達の逃亡を助けてしまい、そのせいで逮捕されてしまいました。
My little brother is so generous that he aided in the criminals’ escape and was arrested for it.

mnemonics.meaning: Dodge a difficult situation by getting away from it. Do an evacuation to get out of there!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その避難梯子はひどく痛んでいるので、交換する必要があります。
The fire escape is badly damaged, so we need to replace it.

mnemonics.meaning: The evening edition is the evening edition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どの新聞の夕刊でも、株式市場の大暴落が一面記事で報じられた。
The evening edition of every newspaper reported the stock market crash as their front page story.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is in the interior of something else is inside of it, deep, and far back / in the back. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 奥にもっと小さいサイズのものも置いてますよ。
We have ones in smaller sizes in the back.

mnemonics.meaning: Somebody doing you fat al would... probably be pretty fatal!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生徒とのスキャンダルは、彼の教師生命にとって致命的でした。
The scandal with his student was fatal to his teaching career.

mnemonics.meaning: The one person title is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the first person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このホラー映画は、一人称の視点から撮影されています。
This horror movie was shot from the first-person perspective.

mnemonics.meaning: All general-al! It's super general. It's general and overall and across the board. Nothing specific going on here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 全般的に、犬は猫を怖がるものじゃないんですかね。
Dogs are generally scared of cats, aren’t they?

mnemonics.meaning: If 遺伝 is heredity and you pass your heredity to your child, how is it being passed? Via genes, of course.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 本当に彼らは父親を鑑定する遺伝子検査を受けたいんでしょうか。
I’m wondering if they really want to get the paternity test done.

mnemonics.meaning: You send your best regards to everyone. Is this good? Is it okay? Is it all right? Yes, of course, how nice of you.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ここに鞄を置かせてもらっても宜しいですか？
Is it okay for me to put my bag here?

mnemonics.meaning: A warm cluster is when you get a bunch of warmth together, and then use it to warm your home. This is indoor heating, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 何で暖房消したの？パイプが全部凍っちゃったじゃない。
Why did you turn off the heat? All the pipes are completely frozen!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: ピザを膝の上で食べるのが好きです。
I like eating pizza off my knees.
レンタル彼氏に膝をついてプロポーズしてもらうには追加料金が10万円もかかる。
Having a rental boyfriend propose on one knee costs an additional 100,000 yen.
私の母は膝で歩くレースの世界記録保持者だ。
My mom is the knee-walking race world record holder.

mnemonics.meaning: Your knee's head is the kneecap. It's also called the patella, if you want to get fancy and talk about bone names.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're walking around in your mom's house, minding your own business, when you slam your kneecap right into that gargoyle she loves (がしら). It hurts so bad, you can't even think out that phrase and instead you shout out, "GA SHE RA" and fall to the floor, clutching your searing kneecap (which has probably broken in half).

sentences: 膝頭の毛が気になって眠れることすらできない。
The hair on my kneecap bothers me so much that I can hardly even sleep.
コウイチが寝ている間に、膝頭に目を書いた。
While Koichi was sleeping, I drew eyes on his kneecaps.
今年アップル社は、膝頭認証の開発を始めるらしい。
Apparently, this year Apple is going to start developing kneecap recognition.

mnemonics.meaning: The reason that ties people together is their lineage or their history. Lineage and history ties people (especially families) together. This word can be used for people with a prestigious family history as well as for historic buildings, especially temples and shrines.
mnemonics.reading: You didn't learn this reading for 由 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you had good lineage you'd never make a U-ey (ゆい) on the highway. That's dangerous, and people with good lineage and a long history would simply never do such a thing.

sentences: 京都の清水寺は由緒あるお寺だ。
Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto is a temple with a long history.
由緒ある家の人でも、いい人だとは限らない。
Just because he has a prestigious lineage, it doesn't make him a nice person.
日本で最も古い由緒ある神社です。
It's the oldest and most venerable shrine in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of loose? It's loose.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so feel nice and loose and move on to the next item.

sentences: このシャツは首回りが緩いんですよね。
The neck of this shirt is pretty loose.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the na-adjective version of loose, so that means this word means loose or mild or gentle.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: その小川が緩やかに東にカーブしているところがあるんだけど、そこが釣りの穴場なんだよ。
The stream curves gently towards the east and is a good fishing spot.

mnemonics.meaning: You know Meiji, (明治), and you know restoration (維新). Combine them together and you have the Meiji Restoration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 蛍光灯は明治維新の頃にはまだ無かったんだよね。
Fluorescent lights didn’t exist yet during the Meiji Restoration, right?

mnemonics.meaning: Join and join with each other. This is a merger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 合 is read as ごう here. Who orchestrated this merger? Good ol' grandpa ごういち.

sentences: アメリカ合衆国は、私が生まれた年にテキサスを併合しました。
The United States of America annexed Texas the year I was born.

mnemonics.meaning: The moon edition is the monthly edition, since 月 also means "month."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 月刊誌『ベーコン』は、エープリルフールのジョークとして、「ノーベルベーコン賞はマミに授与された。」と報じた。
A monthly magazine named "The Bacon" reported that the Nobel prize for bacon was awarded to Mami as an April Fool’s joke.

mnemonics.meaning: The morning edition is the morning edition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You may have seen this reading for 朝 before, but here's a mnemonic to help you: You pick up your copy of the morning edition and Mrs. Chou (ちょう) is on the front cover. Oh no, what has she done now? Before you can find out, the morning edition is ripped from your hands. You look up and see Mrs. Chou running away, cackling, with other copies stuffed into her arms.

sentences: 今日の朝刊の大ニュースには、誰もが多かれ少なかれ興味を抱いているんじゃないかな。
I’d say every one of us is more or less interested in the headline from this morning’s newspaper.

mnemonics.meaning: Play music that will give me comfort, why then I should go see a musical performance to keep me nice and calm.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 千円くらいの、奏楽用のハンドベルはありますか？
Do you have a musical handbell for around 1000 yen?

mnemonics.meaning: If you perform and play music you are doing a musical performance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: バンドが舞台で演奏をしている最中に、電球が切れてしまいました。
The light bulb burned out while the band was performing on stage.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember Nara (奈良)? This is the prefecture of it, making it Nara Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私が奈良県に住んでいる時は、彼女は親友の一人でしたが、私が大阪に引っ越してからは疎遠になりつつあります。
She was one of my best friends when I lived in Nara prefecture, but we’ve drifted apart since I moved to Osaka.

mnemonics.meaning: I have certain demands for goods to take on this trip. Don't worry, it's just the necessities and essentials.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新生児にとっての必需品って何だろう。
I wonder what the necessities for a newborn baby are.

mnemonics.meaning: The open sea rope is the rope that attaches Okinawa to the mainland.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, put together.

sentences: うちの娘は沖縄が大好きで、一体いつ戻ってくるのかさっぱり分かりません。
I am not sure when my daughter will be back from Okinawa because she likes it there so much.

mnemonics.meaning: If you are at an elderly age you are at an old age.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本の老齢年金の仕組みについてご説明してもらえませんでしょうか。
Could you please explain the structure of Japan’s old-age pension to me?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is contrary... this is the te-form version of contrary, meaning you're starting to say something, making this on the contrary.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is like 変える, which is to change. So, if you change what the other person is saying to another way, then you're saying you're changing things. It has the same reading, so remember it that way.

sentences: 善かれと思ってしたことが、却って仇となって友人のストレスになってしまいました。
I just wanted to do the right thing but instead it backfired and I just stressed my friend out.

mnemonics.meaning: I want to suppress and pressure you! Muahaha! This is oppression.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察は、その暴動を抑圧するのにしばらく時間がかかりました。
It took the police a while to suppress the riot.

mnemonics.meaning: If 一般 is "general"/"common" then something that has 的 attached to it is ordinary or normal or common.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 一般 plus 的.

sentences: 大学卒業後も実家に住み続けることは、日本ではそこそこ一般的です。
Continuing to live in your parents’ home after graduating from college is pretty common in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A perfect disc is flawless. It's just perfect.  As you may already know, in Japan the symbol ⭕ is used to mark correct answers. See how it looks like a perfect disc?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that rendaku turns へき into ぺき.

sentences: 私は日本の国歌を完璧に歌えます。
I can sing the Japanese national anthem perfectly.
このファイルを削除したら、これで準備は完璧です。
I'm going to delete these files, then I'll be completely ready.
日本語が完璧になりたい。
I want my Japanese to be flawless.

mnemonics.meaning: A pregnant wife is a pregnant woman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 妊婦さんのためのカウンセラーという、臨時の仕事が見つかりました。
I got a temporary job as a counselor for pregnant women.

mnemonics.meaning: If your interior is deep, then you're a really profound person.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned おく when you learned the kanji, and ふかい from 深い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Most of the time the ふ is rendaku'd into ぶ, but it can be read the other way too.

sentences: 狩人とは非常に奥深い職業です。
A hunter is a very profound occupation.

mnemonics.meaning: We got life by sending back our runner to home plate. That run allowed us more life in this game. Now, maybe we'll win! It was all by reaching home plate. Outside of baseball, this means returning alive from somewhere.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 行方不明の英語教師は、足が凍傷になっていたものの、無事に生還しました。
Although his feet were frostbitten, the missing English teacher safely came back alive.

mnemonics.meaning: It is contrary to what I think is good. It is below my standards. Thus, rejection.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグのメンバー全員がバンジージャンプに挑戦するというアイディアは、速攻で却下されました。
My idea for all of the Tofugu members to bungee jump was quickly rejected.

mnemonics.meaning: A far consider is when you let your considerations go far from you so you don't think about how angry you are about what's going on in front of you. It allows you to have some restraint, since your considerations are far from here. It also allows you to decline things, since you're not considering the other person's feelings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 質問があればどんなものでも遠慮なくおっしゃって下さいね。
Don’t hesitate to ask me any questions.

mnemonics.meaning: If we return and send back things, we will have done a return or restoration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 優勝旗が毎年返還されなくちゃいけないなんて、知らなかったよ。
I didn’t know that the championship flag had to be returned every year.

mnemonics.meaning: Send back to the origin means you are going to return to origins. Make a reduction down to the original.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我々は円高還元セールを実施します。
We are going to have a strong yen reduction sale.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your rope and stretch it out to show where the cutoff is. This is when you rope off something. It shows your territory and turf. Don't cross this rope I've stretched out, it's my domain.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 縄 and 張る put together into one word.

sentences: 案の定、その場所はヤクザの縄張りだった。
Sure enough, the place was yakuza territory.

mnemonics.meaning: We're inside together on this information. Just you and me, inside our knowledge. It is secret and confidential.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はICレコーダーで会話を内緒で録音します。
I secretly record conversations with my IC recorder.

mnemonics.meaning: Choose and select your choice. This is your selection.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の大学では、第二外国語は自由に選べるんですが、どの言語を選択するか迷いに迷っています。
In my university, we can freely choose our second language and I’m at a loss as to which language to choose.

mnemonics.meaning: If you versus (compare) the title of these two things, you'll notice that they're the same as each other. They have symmetry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アシメっていう左右非対称のショートカットにしてみようかなって思ってるんだよね。
I’m thinking of getting a short asymmetrical haircut called "ashime."

mnemonics.meaning: The dance of going to see someone. It's a sympathy visit. Because, you know, you gotta dance the dance of sympathy.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. 舞い comes from 舞う.

sentences: 病院にお見舞いに行くと、彼女の部屋はたくさんの花で飾られていました。
When I visited her in the hospital, her room was decorated with many flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: If you usually lean yonder, in that direction, that will be your tendency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本人は外国人と喋る時、英語訛りの日本語を話す傾向があります。
Japanese people tend to speak Japanese with an English accent when they talk to foreigners.

mnemonics.meaning: 廃止 is abolition, so the verb version of that would be to abolish.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 廃止 as well.

sentences: 教師陣が制服を廃止するかどうか検討しているそうですよ。
It seems that teachers are considering abolishing uniforms.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accompany and the verb vocab version is to accompany. This can be used both literally and figuratively.
mnemonics.reading: You need to accompany your friend, so to call out to them you yell "友, NOW!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.

sentences: 技術の進歩に伴って人々は自然環境にだんだん関心がなくなってきた。
As technology advanced, people grew less and less concerned about the environment.

mnemonics.meaning: The same accompany means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means to accompany. This is only used for accompanying people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は奥さんが同伴するのかと思ってたよ。
I thought you would be accompanied by your wife today.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means avoid or dodge and the verb vocab version is to avoid or to dodge!
mnemonics.reading: Each reading has a slightly different meaning. Here's some mnemonics to help you remember them: You need to avoid people who drink sake (さけ) all the time. Why? Because when they get drunk you'll have to dodge the yo-yos (よ) they spin at you. Sake makes you want to toss the ol' yo-yo around. Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!

sentences: 明日車で母を東京の名所へ案内する予定なんだけど、渋滞をうまく避ける方法とか知らないよね？
I’m going to show my mother the famous sights of Tokyo by car tomorrow, so do you know any good ways to avoid the traffic?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean, and the verb vocab version means to be leaned or to be tilted. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (く) when you see it, because it's already done.
mnemonics.reading: You cut a moo (かたむ), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.

sentences: その松の木は、少し南の方向へ傾いています。
That pine tree leans a bit toward the south.

mnemonics.meaning: To do pregnant pregnant is to be pregnant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は尿で妊娠反応検査をして、お医者さんから妊娠していると言われました。
She got a urine pregnancy test done and the doctor told her that she is pregnant.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bite or chew so the verb version is to bite or to chew.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 狼男に股を噛まれた！
I was bitten on the groin by a werewolf!
私は机を噛むのが好きです。
I like biting my desk.
爪を噛むクセがあります。
I have a habit of biting my nails.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means do and the verb vocab version is to do. This is a polite way to say "to do."
mnemonics.reading: What are you going to do? You're going to become a professional eater (いた), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.

sentences: もしよろしければ私が町をご案内致しますよ。
I’ll guide you around the city, if you’d like.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means draw so the verb vocab version is to draw or to sketch.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 書く, which is similar to drawing something (you use a writing instrument on a piece of paper, which you can do with drawing). Another reading is えがく, which is like saying 絵を書く, but combined and rendaku'd.

sentences: うちのロゴを違う色でも描いてみてもらえますか。
Can you draw our logo with different colors?

mnemonics.meaning: If you consign something to someone, you are going to entrust them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is unusual, but I will entrust you with the knowledge of why to help you remember it! This uses the on'yomi reading and not the kun'yomi, as you might expect, because the す here is the old-fashioned version of the verb する. Luckily, you learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so it's unusual but hopefully not too hard!

sentences: 探偵を託して写真を全部渡したのが間違いでした。
It was a mistake to entrust all the pictures to that detective.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means escape so the verb vocab version is to escape. Also, it can be to flee or to run away. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this.
mnemonics.reading: You are trying to escape from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your knee (に). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.

sentences: 怒り狂った妻から逃げ回っているうちに、スーツがボロボロに痛んでしまいました。
While running away from my furious wife, my suit got really torn up.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ultra or super so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start to exceed the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?
mnemonics.reading: Who likes to exceed everything? Your 子 (こ)! Or you, when you were a 子. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!

sentences: 彼はあまり自分の気持ちを言葉で表さない人なので、度を超す程私に執着していることを隠していました。
He’s not really the kind of person who talks about their own feelings, so he hid that he was excessively obsessed with me.

mnemonics.meaning: If 及ぶ is "to reach" then this is something similar. Now you're doing the reaching, and to reach something you have to exert yourself to do it. Also, you have to reach to the goal you're trying to reach.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that, you'll reach the ability to know this word's reading as well.

sentences: 放射能汚染は人体にどのような影響を及ぼすと考えられているのでしょうか。
What effect do people think radioactive contamination has on the human body?

mnemonics.meaning: You are one and together. If you're together as one, you are together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 一 becomes いっ.

sentences: 「ご一緒してもよろしいですか？」「全然、構いませんよ。どうぞお座りください。」
"Do you mind if I join you?" "No, not at all. Please have a seat."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means presents so if you do presents, you're giving them, making this to give a present.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to give someone a present, maybe you would think about sending/送る (おくる) it to them?

sentences: ファンタジーベースボールの優勝者には、何か賞品が贈られます。
The winner of fantasy baseball will be given something as a prize.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means handle so the verb vocab version is to handle.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually! Can you handle that?

sentences: 夫の連れ子にまるで他人の用に扱われて、すごくストレスが溜まります。
My step child treats me like I’m a stranger and it really stresses me out.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means loose, so the verb version is to loosen. This is when something loosens on its own, and not via your actions. You know this because a cow is loosening things, moo (む)...
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: そのトンネルのボルトは、何本か緩んできています。
Some of the bolts in the tunnel are coming loose.
彼のジョークにみんなの緊張感が緩んだ。
Everyone's tension loosened at his joke.

mnemonics.meaning: To "do maintenance (維持)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is to maintain.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 健康を維持するために、何か運動をする方がいいよ。
You should do some exercises to maintain your health.

mnemonics.meaning: You do one do and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing to match it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The いち is shortened to いっ.

sentences: 偽のベーコンに残された指紋は、マミのものと一致しました。
The fingerprints left on the fake bacon matched Mami’s.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bribe, but when you pay a bribe, you are going to pay something or to cover something, like a meal, or something like that.
mnemonics.reading: You need to make a payment, make a payment now (まかなう) to cover the cost of this room.

sentences: もし今赤ちゃんができたら、俺の収入だけで家族を賄うのは無理だと思うんだよ。
I don’t think my income would be enough to feed my family if we had a baby now.

mnemonics.meaning: If 指摘 is "pointing out" then the verb version is to point out.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from 指摘.

sentences: 何名かの歩行者が、運転者が赤信号を無視したことを指摘しました。
Some pedestrians pointed out that the driver ignored the stoplight.

mnemonics.meaning: The edition will go out to the public if we were to publish it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: マミはアヤに、ベーコン雑誌を一緒に刊行しないかと尋ねた。
Mami asked Aya to publish a bacon magazine with her.

mnemonics.meaning: 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is to rely on or to trust or to depend on. You know it is this word because it is rude to rely on your friends, but you are anyways.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit different from 頼む, however. It's たよ, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become tiyored (たよ). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.

sentences: 彼の事を頼っていいものか決めかねています。
I’ve been wondering if I should trust him.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to return something. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just sue (す) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「彼にあんなひどいこと言わなければよかったわ。」「そうね。でも、言ってしまったことはもう元には戻せないわ。」
"I wish I hadn’t said that horrible thing to him." "Yeah, but once you say something you can’t go back to before."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spin so the verb vocab version is to spin.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.

sentences: おっと。すみません。トランプを繰るのが苦手なんです。
Oops. I’m sorry. I’m bad at shuffling cards.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suspend, but in this case, you're going to suspend your win or loss and try to stake it all on one, big bet. You're going to risk it all!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to risk it all and bet everything on your car (か). If you lose, you lose the car, but if you win, then you were right to stake it all on this.

sentences: 何か命を懸けるほどのものはありますか。
Do you have something to put your life on the line for?

mnemonics.meaning: To step on (踏む) and then to crowd (込む) something, you're really stepping into something. This is to step into or to rush into something.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 踏む and 込む, put together.

sentences: ルームメートが、私のプライバシーに踏み込みすぎだと思うのよね。
I think my roommate invades my privacy too much.

mnemonics.meaning: If 伸びる is "to be stretched" then 伸ばす is to stretch something, where you're doing the stretching. You know this because you took a bus and you stretched it out to be an even longer bus.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 伸びる, so if you know that you should know this.

sentences: 祖母は死ぬ間際、私の顔に手を伸ばし、「愛してるよ」と言ってくれました。
My grandmother reached her hands up to my face and told me "I love you," right before she passed away.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means to take down or to lower.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!

sentences: 荷物を降ろすのを手伝ってくれ。
Could you help me take down my luggage?

mnemonics.meaning: You have ride and exchange, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means to transfer (or more commonly) to change trains.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 乗る and 換える.

sentences: 飛行機をうまく乗り換えることができるかどうか心配しています。
I’m worried about how well I’ll be able to transfer planes.

mnemonics.meaning: A trade (貿易) company (会社) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a trading firm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the 易 portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train stations (えき).

sentences: 三百人以上の人がその貿易会社の職に応募したが、誰も採用されなかったそうだよ。
Over 300 people applied for the position at the trading firm, but it looks like none of them were hired.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are the same! This word also means board and disc, which makes sense if you think about it. Boards you play games on are basically just trays for the pieces, and discs go inside boards (like records) for storage.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 私はビートルズのビニール盤を収集しています。
I’m collecting the Beatles’ vinyl records.

mnemonics.meaning: If you believe you can consign your trust to someone, then you can trust them, or you are being entrusting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はその証券マンを信頼して、投資信託に大金をつぎ込みました。
I trusted the investment broker and invested a lot of my money into the mutual fund.

mnemonics.meaning: The interior person (the honorific さん shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your wife. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.

sentences: 「おまえの奥さんって、どんな人？」「彼女は何でもバリバリやるタイプだよ。」
"What kind of person is your wife?" "She’s the type that does everything energetically."

mnemonics.meaning: A temporary title is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a working name or a tentative name.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: タイトルはまだ単なる仮称です。
The title is just a temporary name for now.

mnemonics.meaning: When you lack stretching, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up yawning.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You've never seen more yawning than when you performed acupuncture (あく) on a bee (び). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.

sentences: 退屈すぎて欠伸が出てきた。
It was too boring and I yawned.

mnemonics.meaning: Your year age is the number of years old you are.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「年齢はおいくつですか？」「あまり言いたくないです。」「じゃあ、別にいいよ。ただ、百歳を超えてるかどうかだけ教えてくれない？」
"How old are you?" "I’d rather not say." "Okay, then. Just let me know if you are older than 100."

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means buddy.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means former.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means hill.

This radical is made up of blackjack and clothes with the six kanji on top. If you see six people playing blackjack and wearing the same clothes you should know that they're all nurses. Nurses play blackjack together to cool down between shifts and they usually don't have time to change out of their uniforms. That's why this radical is nurse.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means reality.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means scroll.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means three.

Raise your fingers to the sky to symbolize that you abstain from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain. Abstaining from doing what other people are doing is important sometimes. So make sure you never forget the universal abstaining symbol.
mnemonics.reading: This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee is endangered. So people started to rally around it, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming this hicatee!" Picture yourself in Central America. Standing in the water, blocking poachers from the hicatee turtles. "Abstain!" you shout at them.

mnemonics.meaning: On your roof every evening you meet with snakes. All snakes know your address. You're snake famous. Snakes go on a pilgrimage to your address every evening. Your address is passed down from snake generation to snake generation.
mnemonics.reading: The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて). "You only give a 手 a night. Newcomers might have a 手 or two, but some snakes who have been coming to your address for years have hundreds of 手s. They are human hands."

mnemonics.meaning: The allocate radical and the allocate kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever. Picture all the jewels you were able to buy because you allocated your funds correctly. Imagine swimming in these jewels. Like a rich duck.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a tsunami coming and you can't stop the explosion of bitterness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and astringent. This word also means reluctant, because wouldn't you be reluctant to let a tsunami come wash you away with that bitter explosion of flavor in your mouth? You're reluctant to face this bitter end at the hands of a tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it. Try to stuff some of the jewels into your bitter mouth before the tsunami stops you.

mnemonics.meaning: A mountain branch will branch off from the rest. Picture this part of the mountain, branching off from the rest, into a mysterious path of its own.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ). If you branch off from the beaten path, you need 1) access, and 2) to be really careful so you keep your head.

mnemonics.meaning: The dirt next to your village is where you bury the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things. Imagine the village where you grew up. Can you see the dirt area where all your ancestors were buried?
mnemonics.reading: You don't just bury dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet uni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive. Imagine crying as you bury your pet uni. Your tears can't save it now. (Though it is a bit ironic, since it needed salt water.)

mnemonics.meaning: You take gold in exchange for executing orders to construct a buzzer. You are a small bell maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living. Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put it together.
mnemonics.reading: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do. Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.

mnemonics.meaning: There is something odd sticking out of the dirt. Oh wait, it's just the cape jutting out into the water below. Phew. It's just the cape sticking out into the sea. Haha, for a second... you thought... no...
mnemonics.reading: The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories. Picture the cape (the land mass that sticks out into water) but it's shaped just like your old cyborg. Weep a single tear.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree crab breaks into your games cabinet and steals a chess piece. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set. Imagine finding this tree crab in your games cabinet trying to make off with your chess piece. This tree crab is big and you weren’t expecting to find it in your games cabinet so you’re kind of terrified. You scream in horror.
mnemonics.reading: Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what? You put the key in your pocket and call animal control. They unlock the cabinet with the key and remove the tree crab from your home. But who’s to say he won’t be back??

mnemonics.meaning: Inside this giant mouth is a person, trapped, because they're a criminal. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals. Picture the criminal, trapped inside the mouth. They don't even look sorry!
mnemonics.reading: The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise. Wearing nothing but shoes is also really uncomfortable too, so it's actually part of the criminal's punishment. They don't seem to know that though.

mnemonics.meaning: When you say "Nurse!" you're ready to defer to them. If you say "nurse" you're asking something of a nurse. For this story, pretend like you don't know what to do, so you're going to defer to their skill and let them take over.
mnemonics.reading: You defer to the nurse because you're trying to save the local farmhand, Jourm (じょう), and you can't do it. He's bleeding a lot, and you don't know what to do. It makes sense to defer to the knowledge of a medical professional. When going through this story, imagine yourself trying to revive Jourm, but nothing you do works. That's why you defer to the nurse. "Save Jourm," you say. "He's just a simple, kinda weird, ten foot tall farmhand with nine toes."

mnemonics.meaning: Whenever a turkey comes in the door, you employ them. Imagine hundreds of turkeys walking in. The word has gotten out amongst the turkey community that if they walk through your door, you'll employ them.
mnemonics.reading: Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away. "I will employ turkeys, but I will never employ children!" you exclaim.

mnemonics.meaning: The excuse radical and the excuse kanji are exactly the same! Dandy! Know your radicals, stop making excuses.
mnemonics.reading: Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway. Imagine all the men you’ve talked to in your life. Think of every excuse they’ve told you. Think of the worst excuse you’ve ever heard. Remember that.

mnemonics.meaning: Your buddy the sheep is part of a flock. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock. Imagine following your sheep buddy back to his flock. Feel the soft fur of all the sheep around you as they baa peacefully.
mnemonics.reading: Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun. Feel the recoil of the gun in your hands and the ringing of the shots in your ears as you slaughter the flock without remorse. BANG BANG BANG!

mnemonics.meaning: In a tree on nine branches are some cross frames. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one. Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
mnemonics.reading: You realize that the frame isn't half as nice as you thought it was, in fact it's totally wack (わく). How disappointing. Why is this frame so wack? Think about what makes it wack, to help you remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to allocate enough gold to buy a gun. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks. Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
mnemonics.reading: You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!  Picture an old fashioned hold up. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!

mnemonics.meaning: A leader who lives in a mountain is a hermit. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now. Imagine this odd hermit leading mountain goats around the mountain, marching to the beat of a drum. It’s a strange sight indeed.
mnemonics.reading: One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur せん. The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel. Picture this old hermit fighting this centaur in a duel. Who do you think is gonna win? Hear the hermit screaming in agony as the centaur demolishes him.

mnemonics.meaning: There are three slides sticking out of this building that lead to your home country. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.  Imagine standing at the top of the building and looking down at the three slides that stretch off toward your home country. It takes a few hours to slide all the way there, but at the end you'll be home.
mnemonics.reading: Your home country is your home (ほう)! Even if you move, even if you haven't been back in years, your home country will always be your home in some way, deep down.

mnemonics.meaning: You loiter around with a gun while your friend tries to correct a stamp to make it more honorable. Someone messed with the stamp machine and your friend is trying to correct the error. You’re loitering around with a gun since you’re his bodyguard. To have an error on the stamp would not be honorable, so that’s why your friend is going to correct it. Feel the weight of the gun in your hands as your friend works to make the stamp honorable again. Listen to your friend complain about how there are so few people left in the world that are honorable. Also keep in mind that the correct radical is a little different with the vertical line going through the top, so just think of that as the error trying to be corrected.
mnemonics.reading: Just as you’re pondering what it means to be honorable, your friend gets shot by Godzilla (ご). Godzilla must have been the one who ruined the stamp! "Go, go, save yourself, Godzilla got me!" your friend cries. You run, leaving your friend and Godzilla to their honorable battle. A single tear runs down your cheek.

mnemonics.meaning: When someone wants to view the reality of your soul, show it with humility. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility. Focus on the feeling of humility here. You're putting it all out there, you know? With nowhere to hide.
mnemonics.reading: As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground. Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?

mnemonics.meaning: You use your foot to kick Wolverine in the face so a turkey can leap to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety. Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
mnemonics.reading: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it. Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.

mnemonics.meaning: They say Mona Lisa had more modesty than any other woman at the time. Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
mnemonics.reading: The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest. Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.

mnemonics.meaning: A drop of rain falls on a bear leaning up against a cross stuck into a mound. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over. Imagine this whole scene. A drop of water rouses the bear and he becomes enraged after he rolls down the mound. Hear the bear roar with anger as he charges up the mound and violently smashes the cross into the ground.
mnemonics.reading: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish. Now look at the bear sitting atop the mound with his head in his paws, looking like a fool filled with regret. This bear feels like a fool for attacking the cross like he did.

mnemonics.meaning: The one sided radical and the one sided kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた). Imagine a one sided situation that you've had. Now imagine the winning side with a catapult. For example, a baseball game where one team is destroying the other. That's because instead of a pitcher, they have a catapult.

mnemonics.meaning: Construction for geoducks doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a paragraph to explain what you're doing. Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
mnemonics.reading: You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application. In that paragraph, you praised こういち for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor こういち when you wrote it. But hey, it worked! Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Criminal writing is always patterned. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters. Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
mnemonics.reading: As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all! Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.

mnemonics.meaning: A building in winter will allow life to have prosperity. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.  Picture a dark, bleak winter landscape. No life anywhere. Now turn around and look at the prosperity on display in the building you're in. Everyone is happy and eating food and not freezing to death.
mnemonics.reading: This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed. Ryu's prosperity has made him realize that having things isn't always enough. Now he's looking wistfully outside at the winter weather, missing the rough times.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth contains a scroll, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the range of the sphere of your mouth. On the map, there is a circle drawn around your mouth showing what range your mouth exists in. Thankfully, your tongue and teeth are within that sphere.
mnemonics.reading: Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything else on the map was accurate, so you take a close look in the mirror, and there he is: a tiny Ken the samurai, protecting the range that is your mouth. He gives you a small nod and goes back to his post.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s an arrow in that turkey and you do everything in your power to recommend that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird. You can’t recommend this turkey. It’s probably dangerous. Imagine sending this turkey back in a restaurant, very upset with everything. Also keep in mind that the arrow is half buried in the turkey and looks a little broken since the arrow radical is a bit off.
mnemonics.reading: You recommend the Genghis Khan (かん) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it. Welp, I guess if Genghis Khan recommends eating food with weapons still in them, you're okay with recommending it too. Eat up, everyone.

mnemonics.meaning: Show your fingers to a giant to show you refuse him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean. Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
mnemonics.reading: What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops. Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.

mnemonics.meaning: The grain stuck in your cleat had a former life. In that life it was a rice plant. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up and cleaned up and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now it's just a sad grain in the bottom of your shoe. When you look at a grain of rice, you should think of its former life as a rice plant, not where it ended up.
mnemonics.reading: The grain of rice, as it thinks about its rice plant life too, mutters, "いな、いね." Yes little grain, it was a really nice life. I'm sorry. You decide to bring the grain back to where all of the other rice plants are, and they all chant いな、いね as you return it to its home. You did a good thing today.

mnemonics.meaning: A big turkey has to measure a safe before he can rob it. If the safe is too big it won’t fit in his getaway van and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs the place he needs to measure the safe. Imagine this turkey as he tries to rob this safe. See him with the tape measure as he determines whether or not the safe is too big.
mnemonics.reading: The safe that the turkey is trying to rob ends up being uber (うば) big. Like, really uber big. So uber big that the turkey can’t even measure it with his tape measure. There’s no way he’s gonna be able to rob this place. Imagine the size of this uber big safe. What could be inside? Probably something good.

mnemonics.meaning: You come across a gold hill. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of steel. Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
mnemonics.reading: You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel. "I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"

mnemonics.meaning: The turtle shell radical and the turtle shell kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean A out of A through D, for example. Cowabunga! You get an A!
mnemonics.reading: With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち. Because this is WaniKani, こういち has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.

mnemonics.meaning: There are hot peppers hiding in this dirt, so you build a wall to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up. Picture yourself walking around and seeing a wall around some dirt. You look inside and there are some hot peppers hiding just below the surface. Phew! Good thing this wall was here to protect you from them.
mnemonics.reading: On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in. Picture some corn cobs. Now picture some hot peppers. Put a wall between them.

mnemonics.meaning: When a spirit stops protecting you, you'll have to go on welfare. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else. The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
mnemonics.reading: While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it. If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: A lively leap is what you do when you do a lot of activities and making great efforts to do them. It's no normal leap, it's a lively one, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: リレーのレースで、彼は五人をごぼう抜きにする活躍をみせ、彼のチームは見事一等賞に輝いた。
In the relay race, he beat five runners in a row and his team won first place.

mnemonics.meaning: The address name is the name that's on the address, making it the addressee. This can also mean name and address. This can be used for both physical mail and email.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 宛 is the same one you learned for the kanji. The reading for 名 comes from the kun'yomi reading, which you learned in the vocabulary word 名 and 名前. So, the reading for this word is あてな.

sentences: この宛名は間違っているみたいです。
It looks like there is an error in this address.
宛名書きの仕事を任された。
I was entrusted with the task of writing names and addresses.
顧客の宛名リストを紛失してしまった。
I lost the list of customer names and addresses.

mnemonics.meaning: If 遣う is something along the lines of "to consider" then a "small consider" is what I'll give you for your spending money. Can I have some money? $50? No, how about a smaller consideration on that, maybe something that's more along the lines of an allowance?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the alternate reading of 小 and 遣う's reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: お子さんには月々お小遣いはいくら渡しているんですか。
How much spending money do you give your kid a month?

mnemonics.meaning: If 南極 is Antarctica, then the Antarctica Range is the area that makes up Antarctica. That's the Antarctic Circle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 南極圏にはペンギン以外にも動物はいるんですか？
Are there any animals other than penguins in the Antarctic Circle?

mnemonics.meaning: 原子 is atom and 爆弾 is bomb. What is an atom bomb? An atomic bomb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の家は火災保険に入っていますが、もし誰かが原子爆弾を落として、それで家が燃えちゃった場合はどうなるんでしょうか。それでも保険金は降りるんでしょうか。
My house has fire insurance, but what if someone drops an atomic bomb and my house catches on fire? Would I still get the insurance money?

mnemonics.meaning: If you abstain from doing things a lot you'll need a backup plan to get you out of things. Someone invites you to the beach? You need a backup. (It's that you are afraid of the sun, say that!)
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Good for you!

sentences: 控えの選手には誰がいたっけ？
Who’s the reserve player?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of bitter is bitter, or more specifically, a bitter flavor.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly bitter. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "She boooo" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.

sentences: コウイチはDDoS攻撃に渋い顔をして、拳で机をバンバンと叩いた。
Koichi frowned at the DDoS attack and banged his fist on the table.

mnemonics.meaning: One sided saying things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in broken language, for example speaking a few words in broken Japanese or broken English.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned for 片 and the こと of 言葉.

sentences: 私は片言の日本語でなんとかパスポートの再発行をしてもらいました。
I managed to get my passport reissued with my broken Japanese.
うちの娘はまだ小さいので、片言ぐらいしかしゃべることができません。
Our daughter is still little, so she can only speak baby talk.
片言も聞き漏らさないようにサヤカはコウイチの話に集中した。
Sayaka focused on what Koichi was saying so as to not miss even a few words.

mnemonics.meaning: A 掲示 is a notice or sign. Put this on a board, and it becomes a bulletin board.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この掲示板は学校のものです。
This bulletin board belongs to the school.

mnemonics.meaning: Your excuse for the current condition is surprising, especially considering your diploma and license on the issue.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今度お会いする際に免状をお渡ししますね。
I’ll give you the diploma the next time we meet.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to consider (遣う) your words (言葉) you are making a choice of words.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 言葉 and 遣う combined together.

sentences: 誰かの言葉遣いを真似することは、外国語の良い勉強法です。
Imitating someone’s speech can be a good way to practice a foreign language.

mnemonics.meaning: Take along your home country to all the other spaces you want to add to your group. Put them together to form the commonwealth or federation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ちょっと待って。もしかして、連邦税と州税どっちも払わなきゃいけないの？
Wait a second. By any chance, do I have to pay both federal and state taxes?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 死刑 means "death penalty?" Well a criminal who has been sentenced to it is a condemned criminal or a death row convict. They're condemned to death.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 死刑囚はこの階段を登って死刑台へと向かうんだ。
Condemned criminals climbed these stairs and faced the gallows.
そもそも、この問題を起こしたのは、あの死刑囚だ。
It was that death row convict who caused the problem in the first place.
その弁護士は、死刑囚にとって有利な情報ばかりを並べた。
The lawyer laid out all the information that was favorable to the condemned criminal.

mnemonics.meaning: The honorable meal is cooked rice. It's the meal of Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 映画を見ながら御飯を食べています。
I’m watching a movie while I eat my meal.

mnemonics.meaning: A flock that has gathered is a crowd and multitude. Because, well, lots of things gathering.
