mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 小さな男の子がジャスティン・ビーバーの物真似をし出したので、群集は大笑いをしました。
The crowd broke out in laughter when the little boy started imitating Justin Bieber.

mnemonics.meaning: A water hermit, for some reason, is a daffodil. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking daffodils, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お墓の真後ろに、水仙の花々が咲いていました。
There were some daffodils in bloom just behind the grave.

mnemonics.meaning: A gun kill is a death by shooting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 犬が飼い主に銃殺されるという悲しい事件がありました。
There was a tragic incident where a dog was shot and killed by its owner.

mnemonics.meaning: Humility is heavy, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be discreet instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember the alternative reading for 重. If you aren't discreet or careful, the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)will find you and kill you!

sentences: どうしてそんなに慎重なんですか。
What makes you so careful?

mnemonics.meaning: A buzzer that will call you to the door is a doorbell.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 呼ぶ and 鈴's reading, put together.

sentences: 大便の最中に呼び鈴が鳴り、男はお尻も拭かずに玄関へ急いだ。
The doorbell rang while he was in the middle of pooping and he rushed to the door without wiping his butt.

mnemonics.meaning: A turtle shell that is patterned has much more effect and result and worth than a non-patterned turtle shell.
mnemonics.reading: You haven't learned this reading for 甲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to know how much you're worth, just take a look at your car (か). Cars are the result of money and hard work. So basically, they say how much you're worth!

sentences: 努力の甲斐があって、そのニュースレターは廃刊になるのを免れた。
Thanks to his efforts, the newsletter was able to avoid being discontinued.

mnemonics.meaning: The employ task is employment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: かつては多くの会社が終身雇用を保障していましたが、今ではそれが当たり前では無くなっています。
Many companies used to guarantee their workers a job for life, but that’s no longer a common thing.

mnemonics.meaning: The English range is the areas where people speak English, aka the English Speaking World.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: シンガポールが英語圏だとは思ってもみなかったよ。
I’ve never thought that Singapore was an English-speaking country.

mnemonics.meaning: To excuse and to exclude, that's exemption.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の祖父は心臓病を患っていたため、兵役を免除されました。
My grandfather was exempt from military service because he had a heart disease.

mnemonics.meaning: An eyebrow's hair is the individual eyebrow hair that makes them up.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

sentences: 三時間前に眉毛をそったばかりなのに、もう眉毛がつながりそうだ。
Even though I just shaved my eyebrows three hours ago, I'm already starting to get a unibrow.
ドレスの色に合わせて、眉毛を染めたの。
I dyed my eyebrows to match my dress.
眉毛を書くのに毎朝二時間くらいかかる。
It takes me a couple hours to draw my eyebrows on every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: A home country person is a fellow countryman or compatriot (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a Japanese national.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アメリカには在留邦人はどのくらいいるんですか。
How many Japanese residents are there in the United States?

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it flock.
mnemonics.reading: A flock? A flock of cows (む)! Imagine a flock of cows, probably flying like birds, because flocks usually have something to do with birds.

sentences: 春にヨーロッパ旅行をした時に、生まれて初めて真っ白な羊の群れを見ました。
When I I traveled to Europe during the spring, I saw a flock of white sheep for the first time in my life.

mnemonics.meaning: Foot traces are footprints.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the kanji, put together.

sentences: 雪の上に熊の足跡を見つけた瞬間、ポケットの中のナイフを握りしめました。
When I saw a bear’s footprints in the snow, I tightly grasped the knife in my pocket.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is one-sided has only one side and not the whole. That's just one of a pair or a fragment of the whole. Stick this onto another word and you have one of a pair or an "incomplete_____."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 片目だけ視力が悪いんです。
I have a hard time seeing out of one of my eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: The frame group is a frame or a framework.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading of 枠 and the reading of the vocab word 組み. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: トーフグの日本語学習教材改革のための枠組みが出来上がりました。
We just made the framework for future reforms in Tofugu’s Japanese learning materials.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 窓枠を木からステンレスのものに取り替えたい。
I want to exchange the window frames from wood to stainless steel.

mnemonics.meaning: Allocate the truth more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached fullness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お客様と末永い関係が築けるよう、充実したアフターサービスをご提供しております。
We provide good after-sales service because we want to build long-term relationships with our customers.

mnemonics.meaning: The branch off mound is the area of Japan known as Gifu.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 週の後半に岐阜の両親のとこに顔を見せに行くつもりだよ。
I’m going to visit my parents in Gifu at the end of the week.

mnemonics.meaning: A chess piece institution is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a Go hall or a Go club (it's a very interesting game you should look it up!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎週月曜日にこの棋院に来て、囲碁を練習しています。
I come to this Go club every Monday and practice Go.
歴史ある棋院の前で記念写真を撮りました。
I took a souvenir picture in front of the historic Go institution.
母はいつも棋院の真ん前に車を止めて、私を降ろしてくれます。
My mother always pulls up in front of the Go hall and drops me off.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: この銃、弾入ってる？
Does this gun have bullets in it?
こちらの銃は、クレジットカードで買えますか。
Can I buy this firearm with a credit card?
外出中に、部屋に置いてあった銃が母親に見つかってしまったんです。
My mother found my gun in my room while I was out.

mnemonics.meaning: The flock of horses prefecture is the part of Japan known as Gunma Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird. 群 is okay, but 馬 is just ま, which is an exception. It's like the ま of うま. Then there's prefecture which is the same too.

sentences: 群馬県の実家から帰ってきたら、知らせてくれよな。
Let me know when you come back from your parents’ house in Gunma Prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: The traces are the people that inherit what you have. They are your heirs or heiresses. Your successor.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab words 跡 and 継ぐ put together.

sentences: 父親が跡継ぎに弟を選んだという知らせは、彼にとって大きな打撃でした。
The news that his father chose his younger brother as his heir was a huge blow.

mnemonics.meaning: A hermit person is a hermit or mountain man.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「わしゃ、お前の真上におるぞ。」と、仙人が雲の上から言いました。
"I’m just above you," said the hermit on the cloud.

mnemonics.meaning: A hit you get in baseball that takes you to the origin plate is a home run. HOOOMMEERUNNNN!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は彼の二百本目の本塁打を見るのが楽しみでしょうがないよ。
I’m excited about seeing his 200th home run today.

mnemonics.meaning: Language when you defer to modesty is humble Japanese. Of course, this doesn't have to refer to Japanese, though it usually does, meaning this could mean humble language as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてそれが謙譲語だと思ったんですか。
What made you assume that it was humble Japanese?

mnemonics.meaning: A needed paragraph contains the important points of what you want to say.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 詳細については、添付の募集要項をご確認くださいませ。
For more details, please see the applicant guidelines attached.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to go through a paragraph in chunks that you can easily see with your eye so you break it up by item.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you out with 目. If you can't see this item in the paragraph with your eye, someone will mock (もく) you for sure.

sentences: 「それでは、アジェンダの次の項目へ進みましょう。」「ちょっと待って下さい。次へ進む前に、10分間の休憩を取りませんか？」
"Okay! Let’s move on to the next item on the agenda." "Wait! Why don’t we take a ten-minute break before moving on instead?"

mnemonics.meaning: If you hop and leap into the air, you probably are doing a jump and leap into the air.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この授業は、生徒たちの跳躍力を伸ばすことを目的としています。
This lesson is aimed at improving students’ leaping, jumping, and hopping skills.

mnemonics.meaning: A rope that you hop over is a jump rope.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab words 縄 and 跳ぶ, put together.

sentences: FM802を聞きながら縄跳びをしています。
I’m skipping rope and listening to FM802.

mnemonics.meaning: One-sided kana is katakana. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one.
mnemonics.reading: 片 is かた, and 仮名 is かな. Put them together to get katakana.

sentences: 平仮名は分かりますが、片仮名はまだ覚えきれていません。
I know Hiragana, but I’m still trying to memorize Katakana.

mnemonics.meaning: To fly and leap is leaping.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は陰謀論が好きなんですが、彼の論理はよく飛躍するんですよね。
He likes conspiracies, but there is often a leap in his logic.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an excuse that permits you to do what you want. It is a license and certificate allowing you to do this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「あぁ、自分がどれだけドライブが好きか忘れてたわ。免許更新しなくちゃ。」「おい、待てよ！お前の免許失効してるのか？ありえねえ。よし、それまで！今すぐ横につけて！」
"Ah. I forgot how much I love driving. I have got to get my license renewed." "Wait! Has your driver’s license expired? Omg. That’s it! Pull over right now!"

mnemonics.meaning: A leaping move isn't just any kind of move, it's a lively motion or sometimes a throb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アヤの最新のトーフグキャラのイラストは、とても躍動感に溢れています。
Aya’s latest illustration of the Tofugu characters is very vibrant and lively.

mnemonics.meaning: An action paragraph is a paragraph that shows the matter or the items or the facts. Sort of the action items, you know?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 用紙に必要事項を記載のうえ、郵送をお願い致します。
Could you fill out the form and mail it to us, please?

mnemonics.meaning: The modesty void is that big pit you go into when you are showing modesty or humility.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その謙虚な男性が実はマフィアの一員だったなんて、信じられません。
I can’t believe that humble man was actually a member of the mafia.

mnemonics.meaning: Recruit and gather everyone to the middle. They're all here gathering for this recruitment because we're now hiring / now recruiting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そいつ、パソコンオタクではあるけど、見た目はイケメンで、今彼女募集中なんだ。どう、会ってみない？
He is a computer geek, but a good looking guy and he’s looking for a girlfriend right now. Aren’t you interested in meeting up with him?

mnemonics.meaning: Someone or something whose 由緒 (lineage) is 正しい (correct) is of honorable lineage, and venerable indeed.
mnemonics.reading: You already know the readings for 由緒 and 正しい so you just need to put them together to read this word.

sentences: 彼は由緒正しい家系の出身です。
He is from a family of honorable lineage.
ここは元々は由緒正しい神社なんですよ。
This place was originally a venerable shrine.
由緒正しい生まれの女性に恋をしてしまった。
I have fallen in love with a woman of honorable lineage.

mnemonics.meaning: A one sided hand is one of your hands, that means you're doing something one handed.
mnemonics.reading: These readings are the ones you learned with both of these kanji.

sentences: 彼は重いお米の袋を片手でヒョイと持ち上げました。
He easily lifted up the heavy bag of rice with one hand.

mnemonics.meaning: A one sided street is for one way only, because everything just goes in one direction.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. You learned the reading from 片 already, and 道 is the vocab reading みち.

sentences: 大阪から東京までの片道切符を二枚もらえますか。
Can I get two one-way tickets from Osaka to Tokyo?

mnemonics.meaning: The range is outside of the range, meaning you're out of range.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: しまった！兄ちゃんが俺の携帯に電話するって言ってたのに、ここ圏外だわ。
Oh no. My brother said that he’d call me on my cell, but there’s no reception here.

mnemonics.meaning: A short gun is a pistol, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: しばらく時間はかかったが、ようやく犯行の凶器となった短銃を見つけることができました。
After a long time we eventually succeeded in finding the pistol that was used for the crime.

mnemonics.meaning: A criminal person will end up as a prisoner or a convict if they get caught!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして囚人はしましまの服を着ているんですか。
Why do prisoners wear striped clothes?
そこには、囚人達の道具がしまわれていた。
The prisoners' tools were stored away there.
その囚人が、1998年に軍隊に入隊していた記録が見つかった。
A record was found that showed the prisoner had joined the army in 1998.

mnemonics.meaning: Prosperity in piles is a lot of prosperity!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アメリカで最も隆盛を極めて入る州は何州ですか。
Which state is the most prosperous in the U.S.?

mnemonics.meaning: When prosperity wakes up it will push through whatever it's in and create a protuberance or bulge. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic for the reading of 起. To get out of this bulge, you use a key (き). The key lets you get out.

sentences: 喉頭隆起は、その近くにある骨の形が仏様に似ていることから、喉仏としても知られています。
The adam’s apple is also known as the throat Buddha because the bone shape looks like Buddha.

mnemonics.meaning: Allocate electricity back to the battery with a recharge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もしよければ俺の車で携帯の充電ができるよ。
You can charge your phone in my car, if you’d like.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take what you recommend and announce it to the world, you are making a recommendation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人事部に辞職勧告を受けた後もなお仕事を続けていたら、窓際族に追いやられてしまいました。
After I got resignation advice from the personnel department and I still didn’t quit my job, I was transferred to a useless position.

mnemonics.meaning: I refuse. I am saying "no." That is my refusal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は戦場に行く事を拒否したため、臆病者と呼ばれた。
He was called coward since he’d refused to go to the battlefield.

mnemonics.meaning: To take a supplement and allocate it to where it needs to be is to resupply or refill  something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 帰る前にプリンタの紙を補充しておいてもらえるかな。
Could you refill the printer paper before you leave?

mnemonics.meaning: If you make a rice plant then you are doing rice cultivation, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the いな reading with the regular 作 on'yomi reading.

sentences: 彼は稲作に没頭しています。
He is immersing himself in rice cultivation.

mnemonics.meaning: A rice plant rice paddy is a rice field or rice paddy.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the いな reading for 稲 and the regular 田 reading rendaku'd.

sentences: 友達はもっと大きい稲田をもっていますよ。
My friend has much bigger rice fields.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the いね reading of this kanji. You can think of it like you're saying "いいね!" at the rice plant you're looking at (just shorten the い).

sentences: トーフグメンバーはみんな稲刈りで忙しいので、トーフグのブログは休刊中です。
Tofugu is suspending publication of its blog because all Tofugu members are busy harvesting rice.

mnemonics.meaning: A gun's bullet is a bullet, though this word can specifically refer to a rifle bullet as well (probably because it was mostly rifles that people had way back in the day).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 少し待って貰ってもいいですか？ちょっと銃弾を取りに行かなくてはならないので。
Could you hang on a second? I have to get my bullets.

mnemonics.meaning: A leap when you advance on your enemy is a rush or dash or even an onslaught.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグが今年、大躍進を遂げたのは何故だと思いますか。
What do you think made Tofugu take such a big leap forward this year?

mnemonics.meaning: The cape ball prefecture is Saitama Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of 埼 and 玉, and the regular reading for 県.

sentences: どうして埼玉県に来たんですか。
What brings you to Saitama prefecture?

mnemonics.meaning: The hermit machine is a giant machine that lives in the Sendai area of Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 仙台に行くまでに地図を買っておきます。
I'll buy a map by the time I go to Sendai.

mnemonics.meaning: Commander chess piece is a game known as shogi (or Japanese chess, but shogi is better). It's similar to chess in a lot of ways and it's pretty interesting. Check it out if you already like chess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 指せば指すほど将棋が好きになります。
The more I play, the more I like shogi.

mnemonics.meaning: A chess piece samurai is someone who plays chess or go, making this word a shogi player or go player.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その棋士は、この建物に自分専用の練習部屋を構えています。
The shogi player has his own practice room in this building.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning for this word comes from the kanji. It's a small bell!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Someone is ringing a small bell, over and over. It's Ichiro Suzuki (すず) being obnoxious, ringing that small bell. I think he's trying to get practice started.

sentences: 退職をきっかけに、鈴作りを始めました。
I took advantage of my retirement by starting to make small bells.

mnemonics.meaning: I recommend this to you, so I'd like to invite you to try it. This is a solicitation or invitation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大学生活の最初は、部活の勧誘をたくさん受けました。
I got a lot of invitations to participate in club activities at the beginning of the university year.

mnemonics.meaning: An honorable excuse is all I have, and that is no good. I'm sorry and I beg your pardon.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 御免。流石に今日の今日で、空港まで迎えに行くのは無理だわ。もうちょっと早く言ってくれたらよかったのに。
Sorry. I won’t be able to pick you up at the airport today. You should’ve asked me earlier.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You take a look at the steel. It's shaped like a person. Turns out you turned that hag into a steel statue. You say, "huh, that's the hag ね?" (はがね). Whoops, sorry hag lady.

sentences: そのゲームで鋼の鎧っていくらだったっけ？
How much is the steel armor in the game?

mnemonics.meaning: If you manufacture steel that is steel manufacture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 賃金カットなんかしたら、製鋼所の工員達がストライキを起こすかもしれませんよ。
If you cut their wages, the steelworkers might go on strike.

mnemonics.meaning: Steel material is steel material. Boom!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 鋼材不足には早急に対処する必要があります。
We have to deal with the steel shortage as soon as possible.

mnemonics.meaning: An excuse from taxes? That's a tax exemption.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 免税店がどこにあるかご存知ですか？
Do you know where the duty-free shops are?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have to aim at.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 狙い, so if you know that you'll be able to aim at knowing this word's reading as well.

sentences: 一応忠告しておくと、奴はお前のポジションを狙ってるみたいだぞ。
Just a word of advice, it looks like he’s aiming to take over your position.

mnemonics.meaning: If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is to apply for or to enlist.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 応募's reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.

sentences: あいつ、ビキニ姿のギャルが見れるからっていう理由だけで、市民プールの監視員の仕事に応募したんだよ。
He applied for a job as a lifeguard at the community pool only to see girls in bikinis.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have humility you will try to be discreet.
mnemonics.reading: Why are you going to be discreet? Because that tutu she (つつし) wears is really embarrassing.

sentences: 電車の乗客は、携帯での会話を慎むべきだ。
People on the train should refrain from having cell phone conversations.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bury so the verb vocab version is to bury as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!

sentences: きっと誰かがもう話をしてると思うんだけど、私達、あの肉屋をあんたの庭に埋めたのさ。良かったかな。
I’m sure someone’s already told you, but we buried the butcher in your yard. I hope you don’t mind.

mnemonics.meaning: If you are going to defer to someone, you are going to concede something. I concede / defer this to you.
mnemonics.reading: What are you conceding? Some delicious yuzu (ゆず). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.

sentences: 彼は、絶版になっている古い小説を私に譲ってくれました。
He gave me an old novel that is out of print.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crumble and the verb vocab version means to crumble, like, something is crumbling or collapsing.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 崩す, so if you know that you know this reading as well!

sentences: ああっ！またお化粧が崩れてきちゃった。
Oh no! My make-up is coming off again.

mnemonics.meaning: If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be to delete.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今お送りしたメッセージを削除して頂いてもよろしいでしょうか。別の方に送信するはずだったものなんです。
Could you delete the message I just sent you? I meant to send it to someone else.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means employ so the verb vocab version is to employ.
mnemonics.reading: You are going to employ more people to your business so you can make more money and eventually buy a yacht (やと). That's the dream life, it is.

sentences: あなたを雇いたいのは山々ですが、就業許可証が発給されるのを待ってはいられないのです。
I’d like to hire you, but we can’t wait for your work permit to be issued.

mnemonics.meaning: You are going to excuse yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have to escape from the person / thing trying to hold you there in order to avoid them.
mnemonics.reading: In order to do that, you jump inside your man(u) car (まぬか) which is a car for a tough man(u) that needs to drive fast, just like you.

sentences: 倒産という最悪の結末だけは何とか免れることができた。
We managed to avoid the worst possible outcome of bankruptcy.
死刑執行を免れるためなら何でもします。
I'll do anything to escape execution.
後部座席に座ってシートベルトを締めていたので、私達は重傷を免れました。
We avoided serious injury because we sat in the back seat and wore our seat belts.

mnemonics.meaning: You are going to untie the person who is in your employ from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means to fire someone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: シャークは事あるごとに規則違反をするので、そろそろ解雇する必要があると思います。
Shark has been stepping out of line every chance he gets and I think it’s time for us to let him go.

mnemonics.meaning: Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is は because you're laughing (HAHAHA!!) at the person who put Nair (ねる) on their legs, then only finding it to be really painful, so they have to jump around to get the pain to go away.

sentences: あのピョコピョコ飛び跳ねている兎が超可愛くてやばい。
That jumping bunny is SO cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leap so the verb vocab version means to leap. It also means to jump or to bounce.
mnemonics.reading: You go to leap and leap again. You do it so much that you start sweating, which is causing a foul odor (おど) to come from your body.

sentences: ずっと探していた60年代に生産中止になったクラッシックカーを見つけた時は、嬉しくて胸が躍りました。
When I found the classic car that had been discontinued in 1960 that I’d been looking for, I was so happy my heart leapt.

mnemonics.meaning: It honorable(y) becomes (なる) that you look at something. This is a respectful way to say to look or to please look at something. The reading を御覧になって下さい！
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もう三階へ行かれて新しい部屋を御覧になられましたか？
Have you been to the third floor and seen the new rooms already?

mnemonics.meaning: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means to play a stringed instrument. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 引く, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...

sentences: 美香ちゃんは、ウクレレを弾くと心が休まると言っていたよ。
Mika said that she feels relaxed when she plays the ukulele.
古いギターを弾こうとしたら、げんが切れてしまった。
When I tried to play an old guitar, one of the strings broke.
彼がまたピアノを弾き始めたというニュースに、私は胸を躍らせました。
I was thrilled by the news that he started playing piano again.

mnemonics.meaning: 掲載 is publication so the verb version of that is to publish or to print.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know 掲載 as well.

sentences: このコンテンツは、過激すぎて掲載することはできません。
The contents are way too extreme to be published.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend. This word is almost the same as 薦める, but they're both common so I recommend you learn them both. The subtle difference is that 薦める contains the positive nuance of recommending things, actions, and people because of their charms and/or merits, whereas 勧める is used when recommending someone take a certain action without necessarily referring to a reason. 勧める can also be used when encouraging someone to do something by trying to cheer them up or praise them, or when offering someone something, like a drink.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as 薦める, since they mean almost the same thing.

sentences: とある仙人から、仙台に行くことを勧められたんだよ。
Some hermit suggested that I go to Sendai.
探偵が犯人に諦めて大人しく警察へ行くことを勧めた。
The detective urged the culprit to give up and go calmly to the police.
こないだ仙田さんが勧めてくれた仙川のケーキ屋さん、とってもおいしかったよ！
The cake shop in Sengawa, which Ms. Senda recommended the other day, was really delicious!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means refuse and the verb vocab version is to refuse.
mnemonics.reading: What are you refusing? You are refusing a child, because children are all bad. You say "子 bad, 子 bad" over and over again.

sentences: 私のかかりつけのお医者さんは、私が大腸癌検査を受けるのを拒みました。
My family doctor refused to let me get the colorectal cancer screening done.

mnemonics.meaning: 払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going to repay, to refund, or to reimburse someone for their payment.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 払い and 戻す.

sentences: すみません、もう不要になったのでSuicaを払い戻したいのですが...。
Excuse me, I'd to refund my Suica because I no longer need it...
出張中に食べた焼肉代も払い戻すことはできますか。
Can I get reimbursed for the Korean barbecue I ate during my business trip?
恐れ入りますが、お客様は鍵を失くされたので、保証金の払い戻しは出来かねます。
I’m afraid that we cannot refund your deposit since you lost the key.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rob so the verb vocab version is to rob.
mnemonics.reading: This reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 母親は、少女に、悪霊が犬の命を奪ったのだと教えました。
Her mother told her that their puppy's life was stolen by an evil spirit.

mnemonics.meaning: To take and return something to yourself is to take back something. Give it back!
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 取る and 戻す. Combine them to get this.

sentences: コンピュータを出荷時の設定に初期化することでこの問題は解決しますが、バックアップがなければ失われたデータを取り戻すことはできません。
You can solve this type of problem by restoring the computer to factory settings, but you can’t regain the lost data if you don’t have a back-up.

mnemonics.meaning: A bitter stagnate is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is traffic jam and traffic congestion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もうすぐ日も暮れるぜ。全くこの馬鹿げた渋滞のせいで今日は一日何にもできなかったな。
The day is almost over. We couldn’t do anything today because of this stupid traffic jam.

mnemonics.meaning: Shift the person and defer him/her somewhere else. This is a transfer or assignment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 校長が権力を他の人に移譲したがらないんだよ。
The principal doesn’t want to transfer his authority to someone else.

mnemonics.meaning: A home country translation is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a translation into Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ロード・オブ・ザ・リングの邦訳、もう図書館に返却しちゃった？
Have you already taken the Japanese version of the Lord of the Ring back to the library?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word also has a few more meanings: instep (the top part of the arch in your foot) and the back of the hand. These are parts of you that kinda look like turtle shells in shape, don't you think?
mnemonics.reading: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

sentences: 左足の甲にタトゥーを入れました。
I got a tattoo on my left instep.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: スムージーを飲みながら壁をペンキで塗ってるところです。
I’m drinking a smoothie and painting my walls.

mnemonics.meaning: A wall's paper is wallpaper.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. It's what you learned with 壁 and the vocab reading of 紙, rendaku'd.

sentences: いつも壁紙はアヤのイラストにしています。
I always use Aya’s illustrations as my desktop wallpapers.

mnemonics.meaning: If 戻る is "to return" then you return on the street you came from, you are taking the way back.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think 戻る for the 戻り portion.

sentences: 戻り道がどれだか分からなかったんです。
I didn’t know which way was the way back.

mnemonics.meaning: You have much luck in your welfare, making you have good welfare and well being.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本の社会福祉制度の問題点とは何だと思いますか。
What do you think is the problem with the Japanese social welfare system?

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means employ.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means every.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means preserve.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means rejoice.

This radical is the same as the kanji, but you learned that a really long time ago, so here's a reminder of the mnemonic, just in case: What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.

Your fingers have to stand up straight, to protect you from being abducted, or pulled away against your will. You're convinced someone is trying to abduct you, so you need to keep your fingers standing at all times, ready to defend yourself. Your fingers are feeling pretty stiff, but you still keep them standing, just in case.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, someone really is trying to abduct you. They're pullling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Help! Luckily, your fingers were standing to attention and you were able to fight off the mighty Ra. He won't try to abduct you again in a hurry. Thank goodness for those standing fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: Every winter you are alert for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive. Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
mnemonics.reading: Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe. Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.

mnemonics.meaning: You attempt to expel wind out of your mouth but lack the breath to blow out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so. Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
mnemonics.reading: You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you. Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.

mnemonics.meaning: It's time to do the mouth sun sun chant. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears. Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
mnemonics.reading: You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him. The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to go somewhere but you're too heavy you'll collide with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all. Imagine being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
mnemonics.reading: You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad. The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.

mnemonics.meaning: The drunkard issued twenty commandments to his people. He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい). Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak It goes on like that for a while...

mnemonics.meaning: The Mona Lisa is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa concurrently," says your art class teacher. Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
mnemonics.reading: Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai. It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.

mnemonics.meaning: The flowers are being worked upon by a tsunami with a specialty for knowing how to dilute things. The tsunami can dilute the flowers by pouring itself onto it. A tsunami can dilute things because it is made of water. You could say that it’s its specialty. Look at the flowers as they begin to dilute. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the flower dilute, you determine that this is obviously a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature. As you continue to watch the flower dilute due to the water being poured onto it by the tsunami, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a super cyborg from the future? Maybe.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're driving, you may notice the flags in the dirt near the exits. These flags mark the ditch running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one. Picture the flags in the dirt. Picture the ditch just over the edge of them. Now look for another way to exit this road, cause that way is just not a good idea.
mnemonics.reading: If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch. It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.

mnemonics.meaning: Simultaneously, you throw your knife at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a dose of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed. Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
mnemonics.reading: "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?" Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!

mnemonics.meaning: A fang on a turkey is elegant. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special. Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
mnemonics.reading: This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle! Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.

mnemonics.meaning: Teachers are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of filial piety. Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
mnemonics.reading: With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち. I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, こういち, so that he may teach me.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk by a geoduck a frequent amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around. Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
mnemonics.reading: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people. Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.

mnemonics.meaning: A horse goes to his favorite district to gallop around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there. Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
mnemonics.reading: Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it. The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of all the spiders is a genius! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything! Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs. Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman is rejoicing. She must be glad and happy to rejoice out loud in front of you like this. Picture a woman rejoicing loudly. She's got a big smile on her face and she wants you and everyone else to see how glad she is.
mnemonics.reading: "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys. You'd be happy too if you'd just found your lost keys. Though maybe you wouldn't shout it for the entire world to hear.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s grass on the ground and the fins there say you have no honor. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor. Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
mnemonics.reading: Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have. Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.

mnemonics.meaning: You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers. Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning. Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the same flag, all the people get together to present a new weapon to your lord. You all bow and say, "Milord, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord. When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
mnemonics.reading: As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows. Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!

mnemonics.meaning: When you go to the yakuza to fix your problems they'll just multiply. You thought you had problems before? Yikes, now you've done it. The yakuza are just going to make all of your problems multiply!
mnemonics.reading: Just like I said, your problems multiply before your eyes and give you quite a shock (しょく). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen. Feel shock envelop your entire body as late payments multiply into more debt, and the number of people mad at you multiply too. You can't even think from the shock of it all.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside that building someone is doing a rice dance. That someone is your neighbor. Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
mnemonics.reading: Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance. Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.

mnemonics.meaning: One way to put wheat in your face is with noodles.  Imagine yourself shoveling piles of wheaty noodles into your face. They're so wheaty and delicious!
mnemonics.reading: Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make noodlemen (めん). Did you ever use to make pictures with your food? (Or maybe you still do? We won't judge.) Imagine you're doing that again, and think about how lifelike your noodle men are!

mnemonics.meaning: Every winter the thread fields become overgrown. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete. Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
mnemonics.reading: The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete. Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!

mnemonics.meaning: You're using your scooter to navigate the flood because you're on patrol. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help. Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
mnemonics.reading: You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot. You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.

mnemonics.meaning: This tree is the master of a pillar. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master. See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
mnemonics.reading: While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished. Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your fingers to shoo a turkey down the stairs and into a portable carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers. Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
mnemonics.reading: You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference. Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.

mnemonics.meaning: Lift the lid off your preserves, kick it, and praise the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be! You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
mnemonics.reading: You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects. If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Raise your fingers to a criminal to reject their request to have your things. If someone is trying to steal something from you, just reject them. "Talk to the hand, I mean, fingers!" you say, refusing the criminal.
mnemonics.reading: After you refuse him, he recites this haiku (はい) at you:  You are very mean / What's a criminal to do / But haiku at you. You refuse to listen to any other haikus and you push your fingers into the criminal's face and walk away.

mnemonics.meaning: A horse is your master and you are merely a resident in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident! Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
mnemonics.reading: To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca. Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.

mnemonics.meaning: You employ a geoduck to review all your work.  Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
mnemonics.reading: As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)! The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.

mnemonics.meaning: The cow of righteousness is always there for us. He is the cow that must sacrifice himself for us to survive. The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
mnemonics.reading: The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing. Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like 義. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: You see an animal with some flowers and a turkey on a stool trying to seize them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers. Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
mnemonics.reading: The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers. Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have gold you also need a guard with a very sharp sword to protect it. You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
mnemonics.reading: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just laying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea! Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.

mnemonics.meaning: Taking a cross with a drop on it, you walk through the rice paddy in the direction of winter and spread your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion, and the drop in case any of that rice is thirsty. Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival. Drip the drop onto any thirsty rice.
mnemonics.reading: You’re actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arab leader) which makes the fact that you’re holding a cross while you spread your arms even more of a big deal. You spread your arms wider than any Sheikh ever has before. Side note: The official kun'yomi reading is just し but since no vocab words ever use し, we're teaching you しき, which includes what used to be okurigana but is never used outside of the kanji anymore. Feel the strain on your Sheikh arms as you continue to spread them. Since you’re a Sheikh, you have to set a good example for your people, so don’t let them (or your arms) down.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of woman comes down from heaven? A supernatural one. She is so enchanting. Imagine your idea of what an extremely supernatural woman would look like, and have her come down from heaven towards you. You're totally enchanted by her looks.
mnemonics.reading: The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう). Touch the supernatural yogurt woman and feel the yogurt. Taste the yogurt, what flavor is it? It's totally enchanting you further.

mnemonics.meaning: The scooter you made out of grains, and are about to ride down the stairs with, is completely transparent. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter. Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
mnemonics.reading: You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back! Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is とうきょう in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone abducts what do they do? That's abduction, kidnapping, or taking captive. This word comes up fairly frequently in Japanese newspapers, and is often used to refer to kidnappings carried out by North Korea in the seventies and eighties.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 拉致被害者全員が無事に帰ってきた。
All the kidnapping victims have returned safely.
拉致問題は、なぜ進まないのでしょうか。
Why is there no progress on the abduction issue?
その旅行者は強盗団に拉致されたが、数日後に放れた。
The traveler was taken captive by a gang of robbers but released a few days later.

mnemonics.meaning: If you seize and acquire you're making an acquisition or possession of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日ゲームをプレイすると、いつもの二倍のコインが獲得できるよ。
If you play the game today, you can get double the usual amount of coins.

mnemonics.meaning: If I announce my commandment and you break it, I'm going to have do an admonition at you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女が私の尻を触ったことはセクハラに当たります。即刻戒告処分にしてください。
Her touching my butt is sexual harassment. I want you to reprimand her immediately.

mnemonics.meaning: The people who will review a problem are those who know more about the problems. They are the advisors.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 明日、部活を休んでもいいかどうか、顧問の先生に聞いてみたら？
Why don't you ask your advisor if it's okay for you to miss club activities tomorrow?
自分からやりたいと言ったわけではなくて、その会社の顧問をしてほしいと頼まれたんですよ。
I didn't say I wanted to do it, but I was asked to be an advisor to that company.
彼は良いバスケ部の顧問だとの評判があります。
Rumor has it, he’s a good advisor for the basketball club.

mnemonics.meaning: The master chanter is the one who is the loudest. He makes sure everyone hears his chants. He's the main advocate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ベーコンの平和を唱える主唱者にお会いすることはできますか？
Could I meet the leading advocate of Bacon Peace?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 贈る, which means "to give a present"? A thing that you give as a present is a present.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 贈る and 物.

sentences: 「これ、君への贈り物。干しふぐだよ。気に入ってもらえるといいけど。」「有難う。聞いただけで既にとっても気に入ったわ。」
"Here’s a present for you. It’s dried Fugu. I hope you like it." "Thank you. Just hearing that makes me happy."

mnemonics.meaning: If everything you do is elegant you have artistry and good taste. So much elegance!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 壁の絵はとても雅致がありますね。どなたの作品ですか？
This picture on the wall is very tasteful. Who painted this?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is best regards and this can be best regards as well. It can also mean well, properly and suitably as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: お母様に宜しくお伝えくださいね。
Please say thank you to your mother.

vocab: よろしくおねがいします

mnemonics.meaning: A 宜しい (good, okay, all right) request is when you send your best regards to someone. This is a set phrase you say when someone is going to help you out and you're all like "thank you for your help" or "I'm counting on you" or some combination of the two. It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 宜しい and お願いします.

sentences: どうして日本人はいつも「宜しくお願いします」って言うの？
Why do Japanese people say "please treat me well" all the time?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is overgrown and will multiply is obviously breeding and multiplying a ton.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 本当に俺たちの柴犬を繁殖させることができると思う？
Do you really think we can breed our own Shiba dogs?

mnemonics.meaning: Presents that you give as a bribe is a form of bribery.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは、ある国では「プレゼント」と呼ばれるかもしれないが、この国では「贈賄」である。
This may be called a "present" in some countries, but in this country it's "bribery."

mnemonics.meaning: To catch and seize is capture and seizure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このメモ帳に、巨人の捕獲についての思いついたことを全部メモしています。
In this memo pad, I’ve kept notes on all my ideas for capturing titans.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 中華 means Chinese, and 麺 means noodles. Put them together and what have you got? That's right, Chinese noodles! Yum!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一日中、中華麺が食べたくて仕方がない。
I've been craving Chinese noodles all day.
母の作る中華麺は世界で一番おいしい。
My mom's Chinese noodles are the best in the world.
インスタント中華麺をヨーロッパに輸出してお金持ちになりました。
We became rich exporting instant Chinese noodles to Europe.

mnemonics.meaning: People who join in a chant group are people who are in a chorus or choir.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 合 is pretty weird. It's a がっ instead of a ごう. Just imagine a bunch of people in a chorus singing "ga ga ga ga gaaaa!"

sentences: 合唱団員は、みんなで手を繋いで歌っています。
The members of the choir are all singing hand in hand.

mnemonics.meaning: If you dilute feeling from someone, they have no feelings. They become cold hearted.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は薄情者だし、どっちの味方かサッパリ分からないよ。
He is cold hearted and I have no idea whose side he’s taking.

mnemonics.meaning: To collide and stab into each other is to be in a collision or impact.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 高速道路で、車が次々と衝突しました。
On the highway, cars collided one after another.

mnemonics.meaning: If you concurrently use one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a combined use. Something that is serving two purposes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この食事は朝昼兼用にします。
I’d call this meal brunch.

mnemonics.meaning: The inside together talk is talk that's only inside between us. It's confidential talk.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi of 内緒 and kun'yomi of 話, only rendakued.

sentences: 当人達は内緒話をしているつもりのようだが、声がでかいので全部筒抜けだよ。
They are trying to whisper to each other, but their voices are so loud that I can hear everything.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is new and sharp (presumably because it's so new) is on the cutting edge. It's up-and-coming, the next big thing!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その会社は最新鋭のパソコンを購入することを決定しました。
The company decided to buy the cutting edge computer.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash your clothes with a dose of detergent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして洗剤一本買うだけで三時間もかかるの。
Why did it take you three hours to buy one bottle of detergent?

mnemonics.meaning: Not filial piety is when you don't listen to your parents. This is disobedience to parents.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自分の家族の不孝になるようなことは、絶対にしたくない。
I never want to do anything that would be disrespectful toward my family.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 堀があれば、ゾンビとうまく闘えると思わないか？
Don’t you think that if there was a moat, we could fight well against the zombies?

mnemonics.meaning: The process of rejecting water and letting it go somewhere else is called drainage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 記念硬貨を排水溝に落っことしちゃった。
I dropped the commemorative coin down the drain.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is superior and elegant has much elegance and grace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は自称「優雅なマダム」です。
She is a self-appointed "elegant madam."

mnemonics.meaning: The things I reject and make exit from (my factory) is my emissions. Poof poof poof.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 植物は二酸化炭素を吸収し、酸素を排出します。
Plants absorb carbon dioxide and give off oxygen.

mnemonics.meaning: You can guess this is an adjective by looking at the い it ends with. One of the meanings of the kanji, enchanting, is already an adjective. That's the meaning of this word, too: enchanting. What is enchanting? It's basically charming in a mysterious way.
mnemonics.reading: So this enchanting and charming feeling is mysterious... some would say 怪しい (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as 怪しい. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference: 怪しい usually has a negative feel to it whereas 妖しい generally has a positive feel. 妖しい also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.

sentences: 彼女には妖しい美しさがある。
She has a enchanting beauty.
その時、ジェニーの目から妖しい光が放たれた。
At the time, Jenny's eyes emitted a mysterious light.
キャメロンは妖しい微笑みを浮かべてそこに立っていた。
Cameron just stood there with a mysterious smile.

mnemonics.meaning: If you reject and exclude something, you are doing exclusion to it. You could also call this removal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 各下水道施設は、下水排除規準を満たす必要があります。
Each sewage facility needs to meet sewage removal standards.

mnemonics.meaning: If you reject others, you are excluding them, doing exclusion. That's not a nice thing to do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本記者クラブはかなり排他的だよ。
The Japanese press club is fairly exclusive.

mnemonics.meaning: The reject energy that you push out of a machine is exhaust. It can also be ventilation, since this is the air coming out and being rejected out.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自動車の排気ガスの臭いが好きなのは、私達の共通点ですね。
Liking the smell of the automobile exhaust is something we have in common.

mnemonics.meaning: A supernatural spirit flutters up to you. It's a fairy!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このチューリップの花の中には妖精が住んでいるんだ。
There is a fairy living inside this tulip.
まさる君の親戚に妖精がいるなんて、知らなかったよ。
Masaru, I didn't know you had relatives that were fairies.
この情報は、特に妖精にとって役立つものです。
This piece of information is particularly useful for fairies.

mnemonics.meaning: Milord (you say very formally with a formal name title). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a feudal lord.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Feudal Lords were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My toe?! NO!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

sentences: 暇つぶしにイケメンの殿様の絵を描きました。
I drew a handsome feudal lord to waste time.

mnemonics.meaning: If you go towards filial piety, you are going to be doing filial piety. Do this for your parents.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 女房が死ぬ前に、もっと孝行しておくんだったな。
I wish I devoted myself more to my wife before she passed away.

mnemonics.meaning: The frequentness of something, measured in occurrences is measured in frequency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どれくらいの頻度で家に掃除機をかけますか？
How often do you vacuum your house?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that frequently departures has much frequency and is a frequent occurrence. Oh, that? Yeah, it departures with much frequency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: みんな、頻発する地震に、ストレスが溜まりに溜まっているんだよ。
Everyone is extremely stressed out with these repeated earthquakes.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is frequently overgrown is something that is super frequent. It never stops attacking, never stops coming, and is honestly getting incessant in how often it overgrows. Those darn [put plant name here].
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お前は頻繁にくだらない事を気にし過ぎなんだって。
You frequently sweat the small stuff.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that goes towards being frequent is something that is frequently happening.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something that happens frequently is something that has really caught on. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so chic (しき).

sentences: 彼は「ライオンキングは子どもから大人まで楽しめるショーだ」ということを頻りに強調した。
He repeatedly emphasized that both kids and adults can enjoy the Lion King show.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who has escaped death by running away is a fugitive or a runaway. I think there was a movie about that once!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 逃亡者は逃走中に病気の子どもに会い、自首を決意したそうです。
I hear that the fugitive met a sick child while he was running away and decided to turn himself in.

mnemonics.meaning: A genius genius is a genius, aka a person of exceptional talent. So smart!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この問題集は俊才児を対象にして作られているので、あなたのお子さんには難しすぎますよ。
This textbook is designed for genius children, so it will be difficult for your kid.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of glad? It's also glad!
mnemonics.reading: Whenever you're really glad to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "Ooh, rays (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is happy you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

sentences: 今日は何だか嬉しそうですね。
You look happy today, for some reason.
百年前の今日、あなたが生まれてくれて嬉しかった。お誕生日おめでとう。
When you were born one hundred years ago today, I was happy. Happy birthday.
最近、嬉しいことが全然ない。
Nothing happy has happened to me lately.

mnemonics.meaning: If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is handling or treatment.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 扱う, so if you know that you'll have a good handling of this one.

sentences: ワイングラスの扱いに気をつけるようにと言われた直後に、案の定一つ割ってしまった。
Right after I was told to be careful with the wine glass, sure enough, I broke one.

mnemonics.meaning: You're so glad, you get glad again. Wow, you're just happily going through life, aren't you? Joyfully accept that gladness into your life! This word is pretty old, and it's used like a noun with と(して) added to make it an adverb or たる added to make it an adjective. Make sure to check out the context sentences to get more familiar with this classical word.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子供ができればすぐ、嬉々として報告してくれるだろう。
As soon as they get pregnant, they will happily let us know.
父は、久しぶりに旧友に会い、嬉々として近況を語り合った。
My father saw his old friend for the first time in a long time and they happily caught up with each other.
コウイチが無事に帰ってきて、村には嬉々たる声が響いた。
Koichi returned safely and the village was filled with joyful voices.

mnemonics.meaning: A famous honor is still an honor, but it is also a prestige to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつは名誉を得ることには興味がないなんて言ってるけど、俺は嘘だと思うね。
He says he has no interest in gaining prestige, but I think that’s a lie.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a prosperity of honor, therefore you have honor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグで仕事をするという栄誉を得たとき、そのオファーに感激して言葉に詰まりました。
When I got the honor of working for Tofugu, I was so thrilled at the offer that I stumbled over my words.

mnemonics.meaning: The inside ditch is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the inner moat. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. 内 + 堀 added into one word.

sentences: 私は彼を内堀に通すために道をあけた。
I stepped aside to let him pass through to the inner moat.

mnemonics.meaning: It's so elegant and so comforting. This is Japanese court music, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it gagaku if you'd like.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 雅楽の演奏会の後は、何をしましょうか。
What should we do after the Japanese court music concert?
