mnemonics.meaning: In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap. This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for 膝小 plus the on'yomi reading for 僧. You've learned them all already, so you should be able to read this as long as you remember them all.

sentences: 自転車で転んで、膝小僧が痛い。
I fell off my bike and my kneecap hurts.
最近、右の膝小僧にタトゥーを入れたんです。
I recently got a tattoo on my right kneecap.
膝小僧の調子はどうですか？
How's your kneecap?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is overgrown and luxuriant must have quite the luxuriant growth. Lots and lots of growth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 庭に雑草が繁茂しているので、この週末に草刈りをします。
Our yard is overgrown with weeds, so I’m going to mow them this weekend.

mnemonics.meaning: I praise you for what you did, so here's your prize to go along with my praise, a medal!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 褒賞を受け取るために舞台に上がろうとした時、彼女は階段につまづきました。
When she tried to go up on the stage to get her prize, she tripped on the stairs.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a dose of something, you are taking a dose of medicine. Take your cough syrup, child!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.

sentences: 解毒剤の極秘開発を行う予定だとちょいと小耳に挟みましたよ。
I heard it through the grapevine that you guys are going to do some hush-hush antidote experiments.

mnemonics.meaning: A medicine dose is medicine or drugs you're taking.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 薬剤を使い終わったら、必ず薬剤入れに戻してください。
Make sure you put the medicine away in the medicine case after you use it.

mnemonics.meaning: You revolve to review the record of the past. These records are memoirs or reminiscences.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: なんてつまらない回顧録なんだ。
This is such a boring memoir.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious mentsuyu , or noodle soup base. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum!
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for 麺 when you learned the kanji.

sentences: この麺つゆが最高においしいよ。
This mentsuyu is the best!
三つの材料で簡単に手作り麺つゆができます。
With just three ingredients you can easily make homemade noodle soup base.
この麺つゆは煮物などの料理にも使えます。
This noodle broth can be used in stews and other dishes.

mnemonics.meaning: What's supernatural and suspicious? A monster, or, if you know the Japanese term, a yokai.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 妖怪さん、何か用かい？
Hey, Mr. Yokai. You asked for me, what's up?
この妖怪はいつも半袖のTシャツを着ています。
This yokai always wears a short-sleeved T-shirt.
妖怪の友達がいるなんて、羨ましい！
You have a yokai friend? I'm jealous!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means milord, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title Lord, but nowadays it's closer to Mr. or Ms.. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Do you know a Lord? Imagine it being someone named Mr. or Ms. Don (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

sentences: この賞状は、中村コウイチ殿の優れた功績を称えて与られます。
This certificate is awarded to Mr. Nakamura Koichi in recognition of his outstanding achievement.
鈴木殿にお伝えください。
Please tell Lord Suzuki.
名前の後に「殿」を付ける用法は、現代では同列か目下の人に対しての敬称として、書面にのみ用いられる。
The use of "dono" after a name is used today only in written documents as an honorific title for those who are equal or inferior to you.

mnemonics.meaning: A neighbor person is a neighbor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の隣人は、幸運を呼ぶお守りを持っていることで有名です。
My neighbor is famous for having a charm that brings good luck.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the movie "Tonari (となり) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.

sentences: 子育ては隣町でしてたんですが、子どもたちがみんな大きくなったので主人と私はこの町に越して来たんですよ。
We raised our children in a neighboring town, then my husband and I moved to this town after they grew up.

mnemonics.meaning: All the near neighbors are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the neighborhood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチ大統領は、近隣諸国との関係をないがしろにはしなかった。
President Koichi never ignored relationships with neighboring countries.

mnemonics.meaning: A neighbor country is a neighboring country. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: どうして隣国の肩を持つのさ？日本人じゃないの？
Why are you taking sides with the neighboring country? Aren’t you Japanese?

mnemonics.meaning: A neighbor house is a neighboring house. That house is right next to ours!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 隣家ではどうやら窓は新聞紙で拭くようです。
It seems that the people in the neighboring house wipe their windows with newspapers.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some noodles to celebrate!

sentences: 早く食べないと麺が伸びちゃうよ。
Eat your noodles quickly or they'll get soft.
苺味の麺を開発しました。
We've developed strawberry-flavored noodles.
次に、麺に沸騰したお湯を注いでください。
Next, pour boiling water over the noodles.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, Okinawa Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

sentences: 我々は、人々が沖縄県から去るのを食い止めた。
We stopped everyone from leaving Okinawa Prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: The outside ditch is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the outer moat.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that 堀 gets rendakued - don't forget!

sentences: ちょっと気が変わって、外堀は必要がないようと思うようになりました。
I’ve changed my mind, I don’t think we need an outer moat.

mnemonics.meaning: You've surpassed what is normal alertness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is oversensitivity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 過敏性大腸症候群に苦しんでいます。
I’m suffering from irritable colon syndrome.

mnemonics.meaning: Milord's hall is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A palace. By extension, this can also mean a sanctuary, and even a hall of fame.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その殿堂の屋根は、たくさんの柱で支えられています。
The roof of the palace is supported by many pillars.
東大は学問の殿堂と言われています。
The University of Tokyo is said to be a sanctuary of learning.
お前にとって、殿堂入りを果たした選手といえば、誰になる？
Who would you say are the players that should be inducted into the hall of fame?

mnemonics.meaning: A location where cars can be a resident is a parking lot.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: ショッピングモールの駐車場で渋滞に巻き込まれちゃってるよ。クリスマス前の日曜日なんかに、こんなところに来るんじゃなかったよ。
I’m stuck in a traffic jam in a parking lot at the mall. I shouldn’t have come here on the Sunday before Christmas.

mnemonics.meaning: You patrol and revolve around the block to make your patrol. You're going around patrolling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 天気予報が外れて、巡回中に雨が降り出しました。
The weather forecast was wrong and it started to rain while I was on patrol.

mnemonics.meaning: A medicine dose expert is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a pharmacist.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 薬剤師は別に白衣を着る必要はないと思うんだよな。
I don’t think pharmacists really need to wear white coats.

mnemonics.meaning: A patrol of thanks is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a pilgrimage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 世界中の聖地を巡礼しようと決心しました。
I’ve decided to go on a pilgrimage to sacred places around the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You'll have to imagine a pillar standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a hash-ra (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.

sentences: そのスーパーで買い物をしてる間、私は犬を柱に繋ぐんですが、いつもちゃんと大人しく待ってますよ。
While shopping in the grocery store, I tether my dog to a pole and he always waits for me obediently.

mnemonics.meaning: Those who patrol and inspect on their patrols are the police or policeman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その巡査は、スコッチを一気にゴクリと半分飲み干した。
The policeman drank half the scotch in one gulp.

mnemonics.meaning: A portable belt is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is portable. Note, this is also a very common term for a cell phone or mobile phone. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 携帯の電源を入れるには、電源ボタンを五秒間長押しする必要があります。
To turn on your cell phone you need to press the power button for five seconds.

mnemonics.meaning: A prevent rot dose is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an antiseptic or preservative.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 古い防腐剤はどこに捨てればいいですか。
Where should I throw away old antiseptics?

mnemonics.meaning: If you're overgrown with prosperity you are probably really prospering.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 信じられないかもしれませんが、私が生まれ育ったこの港町は、かつては繁栄していたんですよ。
You might not believe it but this port town where I was born and raised was once prosperous.

mnemonics.meaning: A machine alert is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. That is pretty quick and clever. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ウェイトレスってのは機敏に動くものなのに、彼女はとんでもなく鈍いんだよ。
Waitresses are supposed to move quickly, but she is ridiculously slow.

mnemonics.meaning: Life, when it multiplies (multiply), is doing reproduction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今、生殖器が二つある女の子と付き合ってるんだよ。
I’m dating a girl who has two reproductive organs.

mnemonics.meaning: Your roofs are spread out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your residence or estate.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 男の妻は毎日お屋敷で何もせずただブラブラしている。
His wife does nothing but aimlessly wander around the estate everyday.

mnemonics.meaning: You're a resident and you exist in the place you're residing in. That means you have residence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 海外駐在員と一緒に外国に来ている妻は、駐在さんと呼ばれることがある。
A wife of an expatriate employee who came abroad with him is sometimes called Mrs. Expatriate.

mnemonics.meaning: A resident of 日本 (Japan) is a resident of Japan. Alternatively you could be stationed in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今夜は駐日アメリカ大使主催のパーティーに行かなくちゃいけないんです。
I have to go to a party tonight that is hosted by the U.S. Ambassador to Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: I praise you for your beauty. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a reward... a prize, basically.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 頑張ったご褒美がもらえることを期待しています。
I’m hoping to get a reward for my hard work.

mnemonics.meaning: Grab your noodle pole and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a rolling pin! You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.

sentences: その麺棒、どこで買ったの？
Where did you buy that rolling pin?
麺棒ならあそこの引き出しに入ってるよ。
If you're looking for a rolling pin, it's in that drawer.
大量の麺棒が中国から持ち込まれている。
A large number of rolling pins have been brought in from China.

mnemonics.meaning: A sacrifice hit is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a sacrifice bunt or sacrifice fly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

sentences: 犠打にならないか心配です。
I can’t help but worry about the sacrifice fly.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum!
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading already when you learned 房!

sentences: 葡萄を三房買ってきたわよ。
I went to buy three bunches of grapes.

mnemonics.meaning: Spread the gold around. First part, I want you to put in a security deposit.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 敷金を全額返金してもらいました。
I got a full refund on my security deposit.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have an alert feeling, you are sensitive to things going on around you. That means you have a lot of sensitivity!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 耳がすっごい敏感だから、コショコショ話はしないで。
Please don’t whisper because my ears are really sensitive.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sharp? It's sharp.
mnemonics.reading: Something that is sharp will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They sue rude (するど) behaviors...

sentences: 私は森で熊に遭遇し、鋭い爪で顔を引っ掻かれました。
I ran into a bear in the forest and it scratched my face with its sharp claws.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is sharp will benefit from its sharpness, since that's all it has, really.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 通り魔は、鋭利な刃物で私の全身を切りつけた。
The random attacker slashed at my body with a sharp knife.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone on sharp alert has a sharpness about them. They are quick witted and have a strong keenness to them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その犬の鋭敏な嗅覚は、何人もの麻薬密売人を捕らえました。
That dog’s keen nose caught so many drug dealers.

mnemonics.meaning: If you collide and attack what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large shock but also crash and impact into them. Blamo!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたは爆発の衝撃で気絶したのよ。
You passed out from the shock of an explosion.

mnemonics.meaning: Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最近では、兼業ヤクザが増えてきています。
The amount of yakuza who have side jobs has been increasing lately.

mnemonics.meaning: You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 愛国唱歌は聴きたくないね。
I don’t want to listen to the patriotic school song.

mnemonics.meaning: You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたの歌唱力をみんなに見せつけるために、このビデオをFacebookに投稿してもいいですか？
Can I post this video on Facebook to show everyone your skills as a singer?

mnemonics.meaning: An alone chant is one you do alone. It's a solo!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 花粉症なのに、発表会で独唱しなくちゃいけないんです。
Even though I have hay fever, I have to do a solo in the recital.

mnemonics.meaning: A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy!
mnemonics.reading: Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for 獲 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (え)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!

sentences: 都会には、我々の詐欺の獲物がたくさんいるんだよ。
There is a lot of easy prey for us to swindle in this city.

mnemonics.meaning: A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 駐留軍向けの洗濯サービスとかはありますか？
Is there a laundry service for the stationed troops?

mnemonics.meaning: A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お座敷のどこかでコオロギが鳴いている。
There’s a cricket chirping somewhere in the tatami room.

mnemonics.meaning: An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日車を電柱にぶつけちゃったんだよね。
I ran my car into a telephone pole today.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute. And something that's been diluted is now thin.
mnemonics.reading: This drink is way too diluted. You sue (うす) the makers for their thin drink.

sentences: コピー機のインクの色が薄くなってきちゃった。新しいトナーを買わなくっちゃ。
My copier is printing with lighter ink. I have to buy new toner.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means dilute, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means to be diluted, to be diminished, or to become weak.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't want your drink to be diluted, so you sue (うす) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.

sentences: 効果が薄まるので、お酒と一緒には飲まないで下さい。
Please don't take this with alcohol as its effectiveness will be diminished.
水で薄まったピンクの絵の具がパレットに残っていた。
The pink paint, diluted with water, was left on the palette.
たった一つの発言でせっかくの手紙のありがたみが薄まった。
With just one remark, the inherent value of the letter was diminished.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxuriant or to grow thickly.
mnemonics.reading: She gave (しげ) me a razor because my beard was starting to grow thickly... too thickly. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.

sentences: 妖婆の庭には雑草が生い茂っていた。
The hag’s garden had grown thick with weeds.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

sentences: 光っている電球の上に銀色のスクラッチカードを当てると、その銀色の部分の下に何が書かれてるかが透けて見えちゃうことがあるんだよ。
If you put a silver scratch card over a bright lightbulb, sometimes you can see through the silver part at what’s written underneath.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 我慢するんだ！諦めるなよ。明日は明日の風が吹くんだからさ！
Be patient and don’t give up. Tomorrow’s wind will blow tomorrow!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant.
mnemonics.reading: Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest  comes naturally.

sentences: 背の高い魔法使いが呪文を唱えると、辺りは一瞬真っ暗になった。
When the tall wizard uttered the magic word, there was a moment of total darkness.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
mnemonics.reading: For example, a car (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

sentences: できれば台所と居間を兼ねるような部屋がある方がいいなぁ。
I prefer to have a kitchen-cum-living room if possible.

mnemonics.meaning: If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.

sentences: 明日、健康診断なので、できれば今日はお酒はご遠慮させてください。
Tomorrow is my physical check-up, so I’d rather not have alcohol today, if that’s okay.

mnemonics.meaning: Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).
mnemonics.reading: A Taz saw (たずさ) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you to participate in all kinds of things, like  cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.

sentences: 同僚の評価に携わるのは嫌だったが、選択の余地はなかった。
I didn’t want to participate in an evaluation of my coworkers, but I didn’t have a choice.

mnemonics.meaning: If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.

sentences: 雨が突然降り出したので、先輩と私は桜の木の下で避難しました。
My senior and I found shelter under a cherry blossom tree when the rain started suddenly.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 先生が腕を組んだまま廊下を駆けて行くのを見て、大笑いしました。
We burst out laughing when we saw the teacher dashing down the hallway with his arms folded.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around.
mnemonics.reading: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

sentences: 今日は五つのお寺を巡る予定です。
We’ve arranged to go around to five temples today.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
mnemonics.reading: We're depending on you to help us to get this car (か), okay?

sentences: 彼の安否が気に懸かります。
I’m worried if he is okay.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

sentences: みんな、コウイチの話に、一心に耳を傾けた。
People hung on Koichi’s every word.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on something or to reflect on something. This can also mean to be attentive to someone, for example your family. This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family.
mnemonics.reading: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.

sentences: 過去を顧みることも大切だけど、未来のことを考える方がもっと大切だと思うんだ。
It's important to reflect on the past, but I think it's even more important to think about the future.
子どものころを顧みると、よくあんなに後先を顧みず色んなことをしたもんだと我ながら驚くよ。
When I look back on my childhood, I'm amazed at how I could do so many things without reflecting on the consequences.
あなた、我が子のことをもう少し顧みてあげてくれませんか。
Honey, can’t you be a little more attentive to your own child?

mnemonics.meaning: 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!

sentences: どうぞネクタイをお緩めになってください。
Please feel free to loosen your necktie.

mnemonics.meaning: To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 取る and 扱う.

sentences: その話題については、次の記事で取り扱う予定です。
I’m going to handle that topic in the next article.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means to miss or to lose a good chance, or to let go of a good opportunity.
mnemonics.reading: Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word: You missed a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was no gas (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.

sentences: 恋愛のチャンスは逃さないよ！
I'll never miss a chance to fall in love!
主人がクシャミをしたので、シャッターチャンスを逃してしまいました。
I missed the perfect shot when my husband sneezed.
ボーっとしていて、アナウンスを聞き逃してしまった。
I was out of it and missed the announcement.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase.
mnemonics.reading: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

sentences: なんだか毛が殖えてるなあと思ったら、植毛手術をしたんだぁ！なるほどねぇ。
I thought your hair had multiplied somehow, but you had hair replacement surgery, huh? I see.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means praise and the verb vocab version is to praise.
mnemonics.reading: If you are going to praise this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing hoe-using (ほ) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.

sentences: どう返答していいか分からないので、人に褒められるのは苦手です。
I’m bad at being complimented because I don’t know how to respond.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you.
mnemonics.reading: After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta ta (たた)! I'm outa here."

sentences: ワニカニのレビューを毎日していたら、先生から勤勉だと褒め称えられた。
I was doing my Wanikani reviews every day and the teacher praised me for my diligence.

mnemonics.meaning: 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this to repeat or to repeat over and over.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.

sentences: 同じ失敗を何度も繰り返すのはやめようじゃないか。
Can’t you stop repeating the same mistakes over and over?

mnemonics.meaning: 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going to select or to choose.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.

sentences: 結婚相手にどちらの女性を選択するか決めましたか？
Have you decided which girl to choose as your marriage partner?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spread and the verb vocab version is to spread out or to lay out.
mnemonics.reading: What is getting spread out? Sheep (し)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.

sentences: 彼に、部屋にカーペットを敷くよう説得しました。
I persuaded him to put a carpet in his room.

mnemonics.meaning: I say my commandment in order to warn and to caution the people not to do bad things.
mnemonics.reading: The first commandment I say to warn them of not doing bad things is I mash (いまし) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?

sentences: 誰かが彼女の無茶苦茶な運転を戒める必要があるんじゃない？
Someone needs to warn her about her reckless driving, right?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is transparent and bright so that you can see through it is transparent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 透明人間の男は、バスタオルで自分の体をよーく拭きました。
The invisible man carefully dried himself with a bath towel.

mnemonics.meaning: My warning commandment is there to make sure you take precaution and show vigilance when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ちょっと警戒していることがあるんです。
There is something I’m a bit cautious of.

mnemonics.meaning: My instruction is my commandment. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my warning. This is my admonition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いつも勉強会で居眠りする同僚がいてさ、ついに上司が今日それについて訓戒を与えてたよ。
My coworker always dozes off during study sessions and our boss finally admonished him for it today.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is diluted to the point of weakness. It has much weakness and feebleness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お兄さんに言われたわ。あなたは意志薄弱だから私と別れることができないけど、本当は別れたいんだって。
Your brother told me that you are too weak-willed to break up with me, but that you really want to.

mnemonics.meaning: You have only one life so do everything with lots of eagerness (懸命). Do everything with all one's might. Go all out.
mnemonics.reading: Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going all out to learn these readings!

sentences: 合唱団で歌う娘の一生懸命な姿に感動しました。
I was moved by the sight of my daughter singing in the chorus with all her might.
ほら、みんな一生懸命がんばってるんだから、一人だけサボるなんてずるいよ。
Look, it's unfair that you're the only one slacking off, because everyone is working so hard.
遅れを取り戻すために一生懸命働かなくてはいけないのは分かっているんですが、中々難しいです。
I know I have to work my hardest to catch up with everyone, but it’s difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: Your interior formal name ender (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is your wife.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: お話中恐れ入りますが、奥様がエレベーターに閉じ込められてしまったようなんです。
I’m sorry for the interruption, but it seems that your wife’s just gotten stuck in an elevator.
